urn:contentItem:5W7M-T9T1-F103-31FM-00000-00Mass evacuations as northern fire grows2019-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. B1Mass evacuations as northern fire growsAir force steps in to get residents of fly-in community to safetyMichelle McQuigge The Canadian PressThe Canadian Press

Evacuation efforts in Pikangikum First Nation are ramping up as a wildfire threatening the northern Ontario community gains strength and cripples local telecom services.

Alvin Fiddler, Grand Chief of the Nishnawbe Aski Nation, which represents 49 First Nation communities across northern Ontario, says he's hoping at least 1,200 people will be airlifted from the community by end of day Friday.

He says a forest fire burning near the eastern edge of the fly-in community has grown in the past 24 hours and has damaged the broadband communications line running through the area, knocking out all phone and internet service.

Fiddler says just over 200 people on a list of residents prioritized for relocation left Pikangikum on Thursday, and he hopes the remaining 1,200 to 1,300 will be flown out soon.

Ontario's Ministry of the Solicitor General says it's working with the Royal Canadian Air Force to fly Pikangikum residents to nearby communities.

A military spokesperson confirms three airplanes are being used to transport residents, with two helicopters on standby if needed. Fiddler says favourable wind conditions have given residents a respite from heavy smoke and have opened a crucial window for evacuation.

"That's why the evacuation is sort of going full tilt today," he said. "We're trying to get as many people out as possible."

Fiddler said the list of vulnerable residents include the elderly, those with respiratory conditions, young children and anyone else whose presence is required to support them.

The community, which is 500 kilometres northwest of Thunder Bay, Ont., currently plans to remove roughly 1,600 of its nearly 2,300 residents, Fiddler said.

The Ministry of Natural Resources said four water bombers and 14 ground crews are working to battle the blaze, estimated at around 3,000 hectares. Environment Canada has issued a special air quality statement for the Pikangikum area.

urn:contentItem:5GDC-69T1-JDV5-F3HG-00000-00Orange is the new green: Troops trade camo for jumpsuits in forest fire fight2015-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSOrange is the new green: Troops trade camo for jumpsuits in forest fire fight

MONTREAL LAKE, Sask. - "Watch out for the widow-makers!"

The platoon commander shouts the warning to about 200 soldiers slogging their way through the dense brush, blackened trees and smouldering ash in the tiny First Nations community of Montreal Lake, about 250 kilometres north of Saskatoon.

A widow-maker is any large branch or treetop no longer attached to a trunk, but still tangled overhead, that could fall at any time.

"Obviously there's the danger of the ash pits and the big concern right now is the burned-out trees - any widow-makers," says Master Cpl. Casey Zaharoff. "And obviously a flare-up."

Casey is one of the hundreds of Canadian Forces personnel who have traded their camouflage duds for bright-orange firefighting jumpsuits to help beat back the flames in an unprecedented fire season.

For soldiers in northern Saskatchewan, for now, orange is the new green.

A handful of homes and cabins in the area have already been destroyed by fires. The army was called in this week to help save the rest and get 10,000 people who have fled the smoke and flames back home.

The help is sorely needed.

Crews were holding protective lines around threatened communities Thursday, but Steve Roberts with Saskatchewan Wildfire Management, said warm, dry conditions and shifting winds could cause more trouble spots.

The narrow dirt road into Montreal Lake is flanked by burned trees, many of them still smoking.

The community is deserted. Several stray dogs follow along behind the soldiers.

It's dry, smoky, hot work. The temperature was forecast to rise over 30 C on Thursday.

The soldiers push through the bush in long lines and climb over downed trees to get to ones that are still smoking or to hot spots on the ground.

There is nothing high-tech in what they are doing. The main tools are shovels, axes and hand-held water sprayers fed by plastic bladders on their backs.

It's challenging, says commanding officer Lt.-Colonel Mason Stalker.

"Certainly fatigue and, of course, the heat are some of the threats that our soldiers deal with," he said. "Of course they're wearing protective equipment, goggles, hard hats, coveralls and gloves."

Stalker said there are about 200 soldiers in Montreal Lake and another group about the same size in La Ronge, the largest community under threat. He expects another 60 reservists from Saskatchewan will join the fight on the weekend.

Roberts said the province is looking for more firefighters and equipment from across the country and the United States. It is also working to train hundreds of additional people to join the battle in the next few weeks.

Saskatchewan used to have a larger force of firefighters, but there hasn't been a bad wildfire season for years and some moved on to take jobs in the energy industry, he said.

"Now we have a new group of individuals who would like to be signed up. We are going to do what we can to train these individuals and make sure that they can join our firefighting forces and put them to work on these fires."

The plan is to have around 400 fighters ready to relieve soldiers in the coming weeks. The government hopes to cut a few days from the usual five-day training course without sacrificing safety.

"The military's mission is to give us an opportunity to raise these resources," said Dwayne McKay of Saskatchewan Emergency Management.

Cpl. Donny Melsted, who served in Afghanistan in 2009, is happy to be of service.

"It's great to be able to help the people of Saskatchewan in their time of need," he said.

"It's tough to see the homes destroyed and the damage the fire is causing and it's great we're doing something to help put them out."

urn:contentItem:4700-NXK0-01G6-81W2-00000-00<published>1998-06-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN REGIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Sask-Forest-Fires ; Wind and rain allow residents in forest-fire threatened community to return</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>PRINCE ALBERT, Sask.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>PRINCE ALBERT, Sask. (CP) - Residents of Descharme Lake in northern Saskatchewan were allowed to return to their homes Thursday after wet weather and favorable winds stalled a forest fire that had been menacing their community.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But residents in Buffalo Narrows to the south remained on evacuation alert and kept a wary eye on another blaze that crept to within eight kilometres of their town.</p><p>The 23 residents of Descharme Lake, 530 kilometres northwest of Prince Albert, had been away since Monday because of heavy smoke from the so-called North fire, which had burned 290 square kilometres and moved to within 40 kilometres of their community.</p><p>To the south of Descharme Lake are the communities of La Loche, Ile-a-la-Crosse and Buffalo Narrows, which are linked together along a 100-kilometre stretch of Hwy. 155.</p><p>Two out-of-control fires in that area closed two sections of the highway Thursday and knocked out power to the three communities.</p><p>"It looks like the fire has gotten to our lines,'' said SaskPower spokesman Larry Christie.</p><p>Christie said the lines could have burned in the fire or they may have been shorted out by water dropped by bombers fighting the fire.</p><p>One of the fires, dubbed Loretta, covers 45 square kilometres and came within eight kilometres of Buffalo Narrows Thursday.</p><p>Today's forecast is for smoke from the fire to blow into town of 1,600. An evacuation alert remains in place.</p><p>The town has an evacuation plan that involves relocating residents to North Battleford, Saskatoon, Prince Albert and Meadow Lake, said emergency social services worker Joy Adams Bauer.</p><p>About 109 firefighters using five bulldozers, six helicopters, five land-based planes and various other trucks and pumps worked on the Loretta fire Thursday.</p><p>Cook said a bulldozer line had been created around the entire south end of the fire to keep it from spreading closer to the town.</p><p>The other fire, dubbed Apps, covers more than 270 kilometres near Ile-a-la-Crosse. There were 28 fires burning in Saskatchewan, 18 of those in the northwest.</p><p>A province-wide ban on open fires remains in place. (Prince Albert Herald-Saskatoon StarPhoenix)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3S7T-7MB0-008G-G36F-00000-00<published>1995-09-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LIFE; Pg. C4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire help lift life from the soil</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY FRANK JONES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> IT'S BEEN the Summer of Fire. First, it was British Columbia that seemed to be ablaze from end to end with forest fires. By midsummer, Saskatchewan alone had spent $ 77 million fighting forest fires, and in August our TV screens filled nightly with fearful images of flames and pillars of smoke threatening communities in Northern Ontario and Quebec.</p><p>Once fire was our best friend, warming our caves, cooking our meat, casting a fitful light on cave walls where we painted pictures of the animals we hunted. Now fire seems to be our implacable enemy, a natural catastrophe threatening life and destroying millions of hectares of Canada's priceless timber resources.</p><p>Yet I was just talking to a guy who says Smokey the Bear has it all wrong - that forest fires can be a good thing. And I came across some surprising new research showing how you may soon be able to grow some of the world's rarest flowers in your gardens, thanks to fire.</p><p>Michael Feller is an Australian who teaches forestry at the University of British Columbia, and he believes we're altogether too hung up on fighting forest fires.</p><p>Regardless of what Smokey says about campfires and matches, fires are part of the natural cycle and occurred before humans were here. Not only natural, but beneficial, says Feller.</p><p>Forest fires, he says, create the ideal open habitat for animals, from giant moose to tiny mice, fostering the growth of low plants that provide food. Many plants only bloom when the dark, mantle of forest is burned away, and some seeds lay dormant 100 years waiting for that to happen. "Fire is essential for their survival," he says.</p><p>Forget wildlife and pretty flowers - what about houses destroyed and all those hectares of lumber lost!</p><p>No one would argue against fighting fires that threaten settlements. But Feller says too often people build homes in remote locations and then scream for protection when fire threatens - regardless of the cost of fighting the fire.</p><p>And the lumber may not be lost, he adds. Timber can be extracted, even when it's been partially burned, and often fires occur in areas not scheduled for cutting anyway.</p><p>Without fires, says Feller, dead wood accumulates on the forest floor, and when a spark finally ignites it, we have monster fires.</p><p>Feller is especially critical of his own province for wasting money fighting every forest fire; Ontario, he says, is more sophisticated, allowing many fires to burn where settlements are not involved.</p><p>Feller's thinking is right in line with some new discoveries I just learned about in South Africa. That country is one of the richest sources of wild flowers in the world; the Cape region alone contains 8,600 species, two-thirds of which do not occur anywhere else in the world.</p><p>Many of the flowers we grow in our gardens today, such as gladiolus, originated on the Cape, yet thousands more simply refused to grow elsewhere.</p><p>Now the secret has been discovered. Only fire will cause the seeds to crack open and germinate.</p><p>Researchers in Cape Town have learned how to fool the seeds by burning dead vegetation from mature plants, feeding the smoke across seed beds, and sprinkling water to imitate the effect of the rain following the fire.</p><p>So far, 185 species have responded, and the gardeners around the world await the Cape's new bounty.</p><p>But, says Feller, thanks to Smokey and those nightly terror reports on forest fires, we've become conditioned "to think of fire as evil. It's no more evil than water."</p><p>Frank Jones' column appears Monday and Thursday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H08-9V80-01G6-94H5-00000-00<published>2005-08-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Residents return home after forest fire threatens Kelowna subdivision</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY STEVE MACNAULL</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KELOWNA, B.C. (CP) _ Hundreds of people in this hot Interior town snaked with famous Canadian vineyards went back to their homes after firemen battled back a forest fire that roared towards their homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But not before they got a scare and flashbacks of the firestorm that devastated the area in 2003. Again this weekend, people were evacuated and flames came within 200 metres of homes.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"When I heard all the fire trucks and I opened the front door to see the mountain on fire I just thought: Oh no, not again,'' said Martin Arsenauld.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"All my neighbours gathered in my driveway and we just stood there staring at all these flames shooting up.''</p><p>As of late Sunday the fire was believed contained, but not under control. In all the inferno, which started Saturday night around 9 p.m., scorched 25 hectares of forest on the east slope of Rose Valley Lake in Rose Valley Regional Park. Flames came within 200 metres of homes at the northwest reaches of West Kelowna Estates.</p><p>"At this point it's pretty safe to say it was human caused,'' said Ministry of Forests information officer Dale Bohjara Sunday.</p><p>"There was no lightening last night, so we can rule out that as a natural cause. Apparently there are trails all through there and it's pretty common to see beer cans, so it looks like it was used as a place to party.''</p><p>A fire cause investigator was on the scene Sunday and was expected to file a report sometime within the next couple of days. While the Rose Valley blaze gave residents, firefighters, forestry officials and a whole community traumatized by Firestorm 2003 a scare, no one was killed and no homes were destroyed.</p><p>In August 2003, 239 homes in the southernmost part of Kelowna were burned when a wildfire raced through Okanagan Mountain Park and forced the evacuation of 30,000 people.</p><p>The evacuation if 110 households in West Kelowna Estates and 105 households in Rose Valley Properties (a total of 460 people) on Saturday night were a lot less than in August 2003, but it was still eerie.</p><p>"I didn't sleep a wink last night,'' said Rosealee Lane resident Heather Harrison on Sunday.</p><p>"We stayed at my in-laws and we (her, her husband and two daughters) were all safe, but I couldn't help thinking what I would come back today.''</p><p>Luckily the fire was stopped from racing through the park toward homes and Harrison came back to an untouched home.</p><p>"You could see an orange glow over the hill. I first thought it was the (Rose Valley Elementary) school,'' said Harrison's neighbour Garry Peschke.</p><p>"Then we got the word that it was on the slope this side of the lake and we had to get out. Actually it was pretty organized, but I couldn't believe as we were leaving people were tailgating the fire trucks coming in to get a look.''</p><p>As of Sunday at 9 a.m. people in Rose Valley Properties (the subdivision on the south border of Rose Valley Regional Park) were allowed back. At 1 p.m. the remained of evacuees along West Kelowna, Klein and Guest roads, Blackwood Drive and Valois and McPhail Court in West Kelowna Estates could return home.</p><p>"We told all the evacuees to remain packed and on alert in case the fire got bad again and they had to leave again,'' said Central Okanagan Regional District information office Carol Suhan.</p><p>While fire crews were optimistic by Sunday afternoon, Bohjara said they weren't claiming victory yet.</p><p>"Yes, we've made great progress, but we still have a lot of work to do. We've cooled down the edges and are working our way in to put out hot spots.''</p><p>Within minutes of the Rose Valley fire call coming in Westside and Kelowna fire crews were in the neighbourhood. The Ministry of Forests quickly followed as did the Joe Rich Fire Department, the RCMP, Westside Search and Rescue and Emergency Social Services.</p><p>"Especially after the big fire of 2003, we knew we had to hit this fire hard with lots of resources,'' said Bohjara.</p><p>"We hit every new fire hard, but when life and property are in close proximity, as they are here in Rose Valley, we really move.''</p><p>The firefighting effort was orchestrated with four helicopters carrying huge buckets of water filled up in Rose Valley Lake dousing hot spots so 60 men in ground crews could do their work.</p><p>Such co-ordination and winds staying light allowed firefighters to take the fire from Rank 3 on Saturday night, actively burning with candling trees, to Rank 1 later Sunday, which is no open flame, but smoking with hot spots.</p><p>Firestorm 2003 was a Rank 5 fire, the fiercest there is, because it burned extremely hot aided by high winds and heavy fuel.</p><p>(Kelowna Daily Courier)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5GDC-69T1-JDV5-F3HJ-00000-00Orange is the new green: Troops trade camo for jumpsuits in forest fire fight2015-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSOrange is the new green: Troops trade camo for jumpsuits in forest fire fight

MONTREAL LAKE, Sask. - "Watch out for the widow-makers!"

The platoon commander shouts the warning to about 200 soldiers slogging their way through the dense brush, blackened trees and smouldering ash in the tiny First Nations community of Montreal Lake, about 250 kilometres north of Saskatoon.

A widow-maker is any large branch or treetop no longer attached to a trunk, but still tangled overhead, that could fall at any time.

"Obviously there's the danger of the ash pits and the big concern right now is the burned-out trees - any widow-makers," says Master Cpl. Casey Zaharoff. "And obviously a flare-up."

Casey is one of the hundreds of Canadian Forces personnel who have traded their camouflage duds for bright-orange firefighting jumpsuits to help beat back the flames in an unprecedented fire season.

For soldiers in northern Saskatchewan, for now, orange is the new green.

A handful of homes and cabins in the area have already been destroyed by fires. The army was called in this week to help save the rest and get 10,000 people who have fled the smoke and flames back home.

The help is sorely needed.

Crews were holding protective lines around threatened communities Thursday, but Steve Roberts with Saskatchewan Wildfire Management, said warm, dry conditions and shifting winds could cause more trouble spots.

The narrow dirt road into Montreal Lake is flanked by burned trees, many of them still smoking.

The community is deserted. Several stray dogs follow along behind the soldiers.

It's dry, smoky, hot work. The temperature was forecast to rise over 30 C on Thursday.

The soldiers push through the bush in long lines and climb over downed trees to get to ones that are still smoking or to hot spots on the ground.

There is nothing high-tech in what they are doing. The main tools are shovels, axes and hand-held water sprayers fed by plastic bladders on their backs.

It's challenging, says commanding officer Lt.-Colonel Mason Stalker.

"Certainly fatigue and, of course, the heat are some of the threats that our soldiers deal with," he said. "Of course they're wearing protective equipment, goggles, hard hats, coveralls and gloves."

Stalker said there are about 200 soldiers in Montreal Lake and another group about the same size in La Ronge, the largest community under threat. He expects another 60 reservists from Saskatchewan will join the fight on the weekend.

Roberts said the province is looking for more firefighters and equipment from across the country and the United States. It is also working to train hundreds of additional people to join the battle in the next few weeks.

Saskatchewan used to have a larger force of firefighters, but there hasn't been a bad wildfire season for years and some moved on to take jobs in the energy industry, he said.

"Now we have a new group of individuals who would like to be signed up. We are going to do what we can to train these individuals and make sure that they can join our firefighting forces and put them to work on these fires."

The plan is to have around 400 fighters ready to relieve soldiers in the coming weeks. The government hopes to cut a few days from the usual five-day training course without sacrificing safety.

"The military's mission is to give us an opportunity to raise these resources," said Dwayne McKay of Saskatchewan Emergency Management.

Cpl. Donny Melsted, who served in Afghanistan in 2009, is happy to be of service.

"It's great to be able to help the people of Saskatchewan in their time of need," he said.

"It's tough to see the homes destroyed and the damage the fire is causing and it's great we're doing something to help put them out."

urn:contentItem:51M5-DFT1-JBTY-W3XB-00000-00Catastrophic forest fire puts Israel in crisis2010-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A25Catastrophic forest fire puts Israel in crisis40 prison guards trying to evacuate jail killed in blaze as government seeks international helpJERUSALEM

A fire raging in a rain-starved northern Israel forest Thursday has left at least 40 people dead, caused the evacuation of thousands of people and prompted Israel to call for urgent international aid in fighting the inferno.

The worst forest fire in Israeli history killed 40 prison guards Thursday as they travelled in a bus that became trapped while trying to flee racing flames, officials said.

Dozens of other people were reportedly injured as the blaze, which torched some 325 hectares, continued to burn out of control late Thursday night in Carmel Forest.

In a televised address, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the fire a "catastrophe the likes of which we have never known."

"This is a disaster of unprecedented proportions," Netanyahu said.

He vowed to use all the government's means to combat the flames and called on Cyprus, Italy, Russia and Greece to assist by dispatching firefighting airplanes.

Hundreds of firefighters and emergency workers from all parts of Israel rushed to the north to assist in evacuating people and battling the fire.

"We've lost control," said Hezi Levy, a spokesman for the fire service in the area.

"I am asking all firefighters throughout Israel to phone in and report for duty."

The guards were in the process of evacuating Damon prison, near the Druze town of Usfiya, prison officials said.

About 500 prisoners from the facility, mostly Palestinians and foreigners, had been relocated earlier to other prisons as the fire approached.

Officials said the bus was trapped by windswept flames.

Witnesses said dozens of victims lay down on the bus floor, unable to escape as firefighters struggled to reach them.

"We saw the bus catch fire," one firefighter said. "Dozens of victims were burned. It was very, very shocking."

The fire broke out about 11:30 a.m. Firefighters said they did not expect it to be contained before Friday morning.

In Kibbutz Beit Oren, a communal farm in the Carmel hills, several houses were burned to the ground. Most of the residents were believed to have evacuated ahead of the fire. The University of Haifa was evacuated as a precaution, as was a luxury spa hotel, Yaarot Hacarmel.

Israel's president, Shimon Peres, said, "If there is something we can say it is that those involved in this difficult event are exhibiting true bravery that symbolizes the holiday of Hanukkah."

He was referring to the eight-day Jewish festival of lights, which started Wednesday evening and which Jews celebrate to commemorate the bravery and miracles of the ancient past.

The president's office said in a statement that Peres had spoken with the prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Salam Fayyad, who "expressed his condolences to the people of Israel on behalf of the Palestinian people."

Investigators suspect the fire might have been started at an illegal dumping site, local media reported.

Israel has a history of combating forest fires, but they usually burn without reaching populated areas and cause few casualties.

Due to the ongoing drought and warmer than usual temperatures, this year has been one of the worst ever for forest fires. Last month, thousands of hectares were destroyed in Carmel Forest and the Golan Heights.

Much of the forest destroyed was part of Israel's aggressive reforesting program, in which thousands of trees have been replanted over the years.

With files from Star wire services

As the fire raged in Carmel Forest, Israel has asked for international help. A charred bus that was carrying prison guards sits on the road Thursday near Israel's northern city of Haifa. JACK GUEZ/AFP/GETTY IMAGES Yaron Kaminsky/AP

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Ottawa commits $100 million advance payment for B.C. forest fire costs</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY GREG JOYCE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VANCOUVER (CP) _ The federal government is giving British Columbia a $100-million advance under its disaster assistance program to help cover costs of the province's devastating forest fire season, Defence Minister John McCallum said Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The $100 million is an advance payment,'' McCallum stressed at a news conference with Premier Gordon Campbell.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"More funds will be owing and I've made it very clear it's a priority for me that the federal government's rightful share will be forthcoming as soon as possible.''</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>After the fire-aid announcement, the pair turned their attention to the province's latest disaster _ boarding a helicopter for an aerial tour of flood-ravaged areas north of Vancouver, especially Squamish and Pemberton.</p><p>But fog prevented them from landing at Pemberton and at the site of a washed-out bridge between Whistler and Pemberton.</p><p>Campbell and McCallum were able to land at Squamish and spent about 20 minutes talking to the city's mayor and other officials and watching a video of the damage caused in the area.</p><p>The summer forest fires have cost an estimated $550 million so far _ more than 10 times what the B.C. government had budgeted _ while the costs of the floods last week have yet to be tallied.</p><p>The fires blazed through more than 2,500 square kilometres of forest and destroyed hundreds of homes in Louis Creek, Barriere and Kelowna.</p><p>The fires also forced thousands of evacuations, including 30,000 in Kelowna when the Okanagan Mountain Park fire threatened the city.</p><p>"I was in Kelowna that night when so many British Columbians lost their homes,'' said McCallum, who is also minister responsible for emergency preparedness. "The prime minister visited the next day and the future prime minister, Paul Martin, also visited the area.''</p><p>Campbell lauded Ottawa for its quick response in providing federal funding.</p><p>"The minister has been quick and our emergency officials said this is the fastest they've ever seen a response to these sorts of circumstances,'' said Campbell.</p><p>McCallum said his priority has been to get the aid where it's needed speedily.</p><p>"Since becoming minister I have made it very clear that my objective is to pay to B.C. and the people what is due to them quickly.''</p><p>While most of the news conference was devoted to the fires, McCallum also addressed the floods.</p><p>"We have not officially said that the floods are eligible for assistance, but if ever there was a natural disaster it has to be a flood, so there is no doubt in my mind that it will be eligible.''</p><p>The relentless record-setting rains of last week caused massive flooding and forced about 800 people from their homes in the Pemberton, Whistler and Squamish areas.</p><p>Four people were killed when a bridge was washed out and their vehicles were swept into a raging creek.</p><p>Some evacuees have begun returning home after authorities ensured their residences were safe.</p><p>McCallum said the funding for B.C. comes from the national Disaster Financial Assistance program.</p><p>B.C. also has a similar program that disaster victims can tap into.</p><p>Under the provincial plan, those with claims pay a $1,000 deductible and then are eligible to receive 80 per cent of their damages up to $100,000.</p><p>Campbell said the province is working with Ottawa to determine whether there are other funds available under other federal-provincial programs to help fire and flood victims.</p><p>"Our responsibility is to lay out the full cost to the federal government and encourage a quick response.''</p><p>He mentioned economic development programs as an example of another source of possible financial help.</p><p>"The issue is how do you identify what's disaster financial assistance, what is economic development assistance.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:46YX-VM50-01G6-837H-00000-00<published>2001-05-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BC-Alta-Forest-Fire-Chisholm, Bgt ; EDS: ADDS dropped word para 3; See CP Photos; With BC-Alta-Forest-Fires; INDEX: Social, Environment</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Bob Weber</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>CHISHOLM, Alta.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>CHISHOLM, Alta. (CP) - Once it was Ron Giselbrecht's home, tucked among the other neat houses in this hideaway community in the Alberta bush country.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By Tuesday, it was a charred and blackened hole, surrounded by twisted metal and ill-smelling burned plastic. The only thing the forest fire left untouched, as if in mockery, was the cheerful orange nameplate at the front of the driveway.</p><p>-BODY- "What can you say when you look at a pile of rubbish?'' Giselbrecht asked in sorrow and anger. "I don't have a home anymore.''</p><p>Giselbrecht and his neighbours returned home to take stock of what a raging forest fire left of their possessions, the day after they were evacuated in the face of a blaze that has been described as charging through the woods like a locomotive.</p><p>Nine homes were destroyed, some as if by a bomb.</p><p>"You're just in awe when you see stuff like this,'' said Eugene Nadeau, kicking at the remains of his son's toys in what used to be his shed.</p><p>Shelly Knahs watched her husband poke through the rubble of her parent's home, in which she grew up. He held up a pair of ceramic figurines, their colours bleached by the heat of fire.</p><p>"Isn't that sad,'' she said. "There are the little statues that stood on their coffee table.''</p><p>"Do you want them?'' her husband asked.</p><p>"No. They're junk now,'' Knahs responded.</p><p>Dale Wade drove out from nearby Westlock to survey the ruins of his cabin.</p><p>"There's nothing there at all,'' he said. "It's flattened. Melted. My Ski-Doos are just melted down to little piles of nuthin's.''</p><p>But the fire was oddly selective.</p><p>A child's swing set stood undamaged beside a house in ruins, its cheerful blue and white paint not even scorched. A line of laundry hung unmarked by a single ember, while a few yards away the fire burned hot enough to melt the zinc coating off the wheel wells of an off-road vehicle.</p><p>"I couldn't believe it,'' said Giselbrecht.</p><p>"My house was gone. The ones that I figured would be gone, some of them are still standing.''</p><p>Chisholm was a nice little community with a couple dozen permanent residents and a growing population of cottagers, said Giselbrecht.</p><p>On weekends, the place would be full of people enjoying the woods and the nearby Athabasca River, driving quads and snow machines. Now, he doesn't know what's going to happen.</p><p>"It's too soon. It's too soon.''</p><p>Al Pearson lost a brand-new log home, as well as the trailer he'd renovated for his mother. He doesn't know what the future will bring, either.</p><p>"I'll go back to the city, I guess. What can you do? You can't even salvage anything.''</p><p>But some residents felt none of the loss was necessary. Several harangued a forestry official while an RCMP officer stood by to keep the peace.</p><p>"If they'd have went to work the night this fire started there wouldn't have been a fire,'' said Giselbrecht.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5SRW-6P41-JDH3-G281-00000-00Camp fires, fireworks banned in West Parry Sound2018-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Camp fires, fireworks banned in West Parry Sound

PARRY SOUND - Fires are banned in West Parry Sound.

During an 'extreme' fire rating camp fires are prohibited in all seven townships, as are fireworks in Archipelago, Carling, McDougall, McKellar and Whitestone.

The decision to go from a rating of 'high' to 'extreme' the morning of Thursday, July 5 takes into account the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry's fire rating, fires in the northeast of the province and the hot weather.

"By late afternoon (of Wednesday, July 4), there were forty-three active forest fires across the Northeast. Nineteen of these fires are not yet under control, while twenty-four are either being held, under control or being observed," according to Ontario's forest fire website. "Recent periods of heavy lightning observed over the Canada Day long weekend have sparked several new fires in the Sudbury and North Bay regions."

The 'extreme' fire rating in West Parry Sound is expected to last into next week, said McDougall Fire Chief Brian Leduc Thursday.

"Don't take chances, don't burn, don't light fireworks; if someone starts a fire they are financially responsible for the suppression costs of that fire," he said.

In McKellar, setting off fireworks during a fire ban or in extreme conditions is a $355 fine.

urn:contentItem:4624-V550-01G6-90V0-00000-00<published>2002-06-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire smoke in northern Alta. forces evacuation of aboriginal community</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FOX LAKE, Alta. (CP) _ Hundreds of people from an isolated aboriginal settlement in northern Alberta opted to leave their homes Wednesday as a growing forest fire threatened their community.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 700 people from Fox Lake, one of three reserves that make up the Little Red River Cree Nation, took a barge across the Peace River to John D'Or Prairie, a community still deemed safe from the advancing flames.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>About 100 people had already been airlifted to the town of High Level on Tuesday because of thick smoke from the 50-square-kilometre fire. Elders, infants, the ill and expectant mothers were chosen for the airlift because they were considered to be at high risk from the choking smoke.</p><p>Dianne Hunter, director of disaster services and town manager for High Level, said the airlift was stressful for the inhabitants.</p><p> This community is a fairly isolated community, so for most of them it's just the stress of being away from something that's familiar and (being) in a community that's not familiar to themselves,'' Hunter said.</p><p> A lot of them do not speak English. Their native language is Cree.''</p><p>She said interpreters were being brought in to explain the status of the fire to the evacuees. Volunteers were also making bannock and stew to try to make them feel more at home.</p><p>The blaze was about 110 kilometres east of Fort Vermilion and just a few kilometres from the reserve's edge, said wildfire information officer Kim Morton. Another fire covering about 22 square kilometres was also burning about 80 kilometres to the south.</p><p>Both were out of control.</p><p>Fox Lake, about 550 kilometres north of Edmonton, is only accessible by boat or plane. About 2,600 people live scattered throughout the reserve, which is just west of Wood Buffalo National Park.</p><p>Morton said the combination of temperatures expected to top out at 29 C. Wednesday, no rain and light winds could cause erratic fire behaviour.''</p><p> Definitely the weather conditions are a concern with the high temperatures and the low relative humidity,'' he said. The winds, even though they're light, can pose problems.''</p><p>Strong winds and warm temperatures were also hampering efforts to put out hot spots in the large House River fire south of Fort McMurray. That fire, which has been held for a number of days, has burned about 2,750 square kilometres _ an area half the size of Prince Edward Island.</p><p> We are still trying to make progress, but it's a large fire,'' said Rick Strickland, another information officer. It's difficult working on the hot spots with the warm weather conditions.''</p><p>However, an alert status for nearby residents of Conklin was lifted Tuesday and secondary highways in the area were reopened.</p><p>Further south, about 200 weary residents from the Sunchild reserve in west-central Alberta were allowed to go home after evacuating last Thursday. The blaze that had threatened their houses was under control and a bulldozed guard around the fire was completed.</p><p> They are pretty relieved. This has been a long time and we are happy to go home,'' said Chief Melvin Goodrunning.</p><p>Another stubborn blaze near Redwater, about an hour's drive north of Edmonton, saw crews still fighting hot spots within the fire perimeter.</p><p>Residents remained on evacuation alert and were being asked to conserve water. The fire destroyed four homes and numerous workshops and sheds two weeks ago.</p><p>Brush and grass fires west of Edmonton were also causing problems. One couple escaped with only the clothes on their backs as flaming pieces of poplar fluff ignited their home within minutes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5SRN-7RS1-F105-64N4-00000-00Camp fires, fireworks banned in West Parry Sound2018-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYPg. 1Camp fires, fireworks banned in West Parry Sound

PARRY SOUND - Fires are banned in West Parry Sound.

During an 'extreme' fire rating camp fires are prohibited in all seven townships, as are fireworks in Archipelago, Carling, McDougall, McKellar and Whitestone.

The decision to go from a rating of 'high' to 'extreme' the morning of Thursday, July 5 takes into account the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry's fire rating, fires in the northeast of the province and the hot weather.

"By late afternoon (of Wednesday, July 4), there were forty-three active forest fires across the Northeast. Nineteen of these fires are not yet under control, while twenty-four are either being held, under control or being observed," according to Ontario's forest fire website. "Recent periods of heavy lightning observed over the Canada Day long weekend have sparked several new fires in the Sudbury and North Bay regions."

The 'extreme' fire rating in West Parry Sound is expected to last into next week, said McDougall Fire Chief Brian Leduc Thursday.

"Don't take chances, don't burn, don't light fireworks; if someone starts a fire they are financially responsible for the suppression costs of that fire," he said.

In McKellar, setting off fireworks during a fire ban or in extreme conditions is a $355 fine.

urn:contentItem:5W7P-04V1-JDH1-C022-00000-00Demonstrators gather to demand a voice on North Cowichan municipal forest reserve2019-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSDemonstrators gather to demand a voice on North Cowichan municipal forest reserveRobert Barron

With the growing impacts of climate change, forestry practices in North Cowichan's municipal forest reserve must change, according to Chris Istace.

Istace was one of numerous speakers to address an enthusiastic, placard-waving crowd of about 100 people that gathered at North Cowichan's municipal hall on May 29 to protest council's plan to harvest trees that blew down or were heavily damaged during last December's windstorm in the 5,000-hectare municipal forest reserve.

Of particular concern are plans for the harvesting of wood in the ecologically sensitive Stoney Hill area.

Istace said the people gathered at the hall are not against North Cowichan's council and staff on issues regarding the forest reserve, but are there for them as they make fundamental decisions regarding the community property.

"We want to look at doing things differently and try to find the right balance in ensuring the reserve is dealt with in a sustainable manner," Istace said.

"It's been 22 years since the last management plan for the reserve was written and the climate has changed a lot since then. We don't know everything but the science and the will is there (to do it right)."

In February, council endorsed just the completion of existing 2018 forestry contracts and harvesting of blow downs from December's windstorm in the municipal forest reserve in 2019 until experts are tapped for their input and the public has been thoroughly consulted on what people want for the future of the public properties.

RELATED STORY: NORTH COWICHAN TO PAUSE ALL LOGGING IN FOREST RESERVE FOR 2019

But activities within the reserve since then, particularly plans to remove the blow downs on Stoney Hill, and the fact there still has been no significant public consultations on future plans for the reserve with just months to go before the new year, has raised concerns.

RELATED STORY: NORTH COWICHAN ENDORSES HARVESTING OF BLOW-DOWN TREES IN RESERVE

With work now beginning on harvesting of thousands of cubic metres of blown down and/or damaged trees in the reserve, including 1,800 cubic metres on Stoney Hill, concerned citizens decided to hold the demonstration on Wednesday.

Icel Dobell from the Where do we Stand group, said the consequences of harvesting wood on Stoney Hill are clear.

"Where we have logged for the past 12 years there are now clear-cuts full of four- to six-foot high Scotch broom, small trees and tall grass that are a recipe for fire," she said.

"We may not be able to change the world, but we can change how we manage the community forests here and now before the contract is signed for the salvage logging of Stoney Hill."

Sierra Robinson, from the Cowichan branch of the Earth Guardians, said people need to use their voices to be heard and advocate for change.

"The power of the people is more powerful than the people in power," she said.

North Cowichan councillor Christopher Justice advocated in December for the municipality to stop its logging plans in the Stoney Hill area until a community discussion is held on the issue.

RELATED STORY: JUSTICE CALLING FOR PAUSE IN MUNICIPAL LOGGING PLANS FOR STONEY HILL

He said Wednesday that while he feels that Stoney Hill should never be logged for profit again, that's not to say that it should not be managed and that management may necessitate cutting and removing some trees for certain purposes.

"Until all the evidence and opinions are considered and we have agreed, as a community, that we are prepared to accept whatever enhanced risk of disease and forest fire that accrue from leaving the blow down where it lies, I think it would be irresponsible of council to not follow the advice of our professional forester," Justice said.

"For this reason, and at this moment, I think removing the blow down is the right decision and one that needs to be hastily acted on."

Mayor Al Siebring said he acknowledges the people who demonstrated at the municipal hall were fully entitled to protest and express themselves.

But he said he believes the demonstration was largely a result of a misunderstanding.

"We are committed to engaging in consultations with the public on the future of the reserve, but not for planning in 2019," Siebring said.

"We are looking at longer-term planning; from 2020 and beyond. A staff report on how to proceed with community consultations is coming soon and we'll see what that looks like in regards to the highest and best use of the reserve's forests. In the meantime, we made a decision not to just stop everything."

Siebring said council has been advised by its recently expanded forest advisory committee that taking out the blown-down trees in the reserve is the best way to deal with forest fire hazards, beetles and safety issues related to recreational uses in those areas.

urn:contentItem:4702-0K30-01G6-83SJ-00000-00<published>1999-05-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PM-Forest-Fires, ; WPG OUT WQQ; Budget; EDS: ADDS Bearskin Lake evacuation para 8; INDEX: Environment; Forest-fire evacuees save treasures</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kimberly Hicks</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal</p><p nitf:lede="true">THUNDER BAY, Ont. (CP) - Diane Butay was almost out the door of her home when she noticed a tiny white porcelain shoe passed down from her great-grandmother.</p><p nitf:lede="true">She gently removed it from a shelf and placed it in her bag.</p><p>-BODY- The shoe is a priceless family heirloom that could never be replaced if her home is claimed by a forest fire that was quickly closing in on the Beardmore community.</p><p>"My daughter is expecting this summer, and it goes to my daughter's daughter,'' said Butay as tears welled up in her eyes.</p><p>The Ministry of Natural Resources declared much of Northern Ontario a restricted fire zone as more than four-dozen fires raged across the area.</p><p>The largest fire, a 10,000-hectare blaze, led to the evacuation Tuesday of Beardmore, near Lake Nipigon.</p><p>About 300 residents were taken to Geraldton, about 80 kilometres to the east, and at least seven lakeside cottages were destroyed by the blaze.</p><p>In Sioux Lookout, Ont., a fire was threatening the First Nations community of Bearskin Lake, which sent 125 of its residents to Geraldton. Another 400 residents of the reserve were to be flown to Geraldton today.</p><p>A 500-hectare blaze near Chapleau is burning out of control and a 60-hectare fire was burning about 25 kilometres north of Hornepayne.</p><p>Recent mild winter, an early snow melt, a lack of spring rain and unseasonably warm temperatures have all contributed to the fire hazard.</p><p>Butay had been packing clothing since she was told of the evacuation alert Sunday. But as the fire closed in on the northwestern Ontario community, she began to pack up things in her house that she knew couldn't be replaced.</p><p>She also had to leave her two dogs and two cats behind because no pets are allowed at the emergency centres.</p><p>"I couldn't bring my pets on the bus and I just sat there and cried,'' said Butay.</p><p>She was told that if the fire makes it to the community, the animals will be released to fend for themselves.</p><p>A wooden hydro pole burned by a forest fire resulted in power being cut to the town of White River and the three Hemlo gold mines Tuesday afternoon.</p><p>Another stubborn fire south of Temagami continued to burn. The fire began Sunday afternoon and forced more than 20 people to evacuate their homes. They returned Monday.</p><p>In Manitoba, firefighters cautiously claimed victory over a massive fire east of Lake Winnipeg.</p><p>Fire boss Ken Ulrich said while the fire near Manigotagan continues to be officially classified as "out of control,'' workers have successfully contained it.</p><p>"It's a sleeping giant right now,'' Ulrich said Tuesday in Pine Falls. "It hasn't expanded any, but we'll have to watch the weather.''</p><p>It forced more than 600 people from their homes and destroyed the Rice River Bridge across Highway 304. No homes were damaged.</p><p>Another fire near the Island Lake reserve of St. Theresa Point, about 500 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg, forced the 57 people out of their homes on Sunday.</p><p>(Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal; Winnipeg Free Press)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5W5J-7K71-F103-3452-00000-00Surrey firefighters not among 267 being sent to battle Alberta wildfires2019-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSSurrey firefighters not among 267 being sent to battle Alberta wildfires

Surrey firefighters are not among the 267 B.C. emergency responders being sent to Alberta this week to battle wildfires there.

A BC Wildfire Service bulletin issued Tuesday indicated that on May 23-23 some 230 B.C. firefighters - 10 "attack" crews and 10 unit crews among them - would be sent to our neighbouring province, along with 14 supervisors, three government representatives and a 20-member incident management team.

"We haven't been called upon to be deployed," Surrey Fire Chief Len Garis told the Now-Leader on Tuesday. "I'm thinking that they may not be structural forces because I have simply not heard about that. It's probably forest fire fighting folks as opposed to structural, but I'm just speculating on that."

Surrey Fire Chief Len Garis. (Photo: Tom Zytaruk)

READ ALSO: B.C. sends 267 firefighters to help battle Alberta wildfires

READ ALSO UPDATE: No one hurt in fire at Surrey care facility

Crews can be deployed outside B.C. for up to 19 days but may be recalled at any time, noted Kyla Fraser, fire information officer for the BC Wildlife Service.

"The BC Wildfire Service recognizes the importance of sharing firefighting resources given the invaluable assistance Alberta has provided to B.C. during the last two wildfire seasons, which were the worst in the province's history," she noted.

Garis said that in anticipation of the season coming up, Surrey Fire Service has been asked to provide an inventory of resources, "as we normally do," that might be issued or sent "if called upon, and that's co-ordinated through the office of the fire commissioner of the province.

"In many cases they normally start with the smaller volunteer departments because they are somewhat more flexible," Garis noted.

urn:contentItem:4702-0K10-01G6-830M-00000-00<published>1999-05-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Mba-Forest-Fires, ; WPG OUT WQQ; EDS: ADDS Ontario fire; INDEX: Forestry, Social, Environment; Forest fire forces 600 from homes</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>BISSETT, Man.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>BISSETT, Man. (CP) - About 600 people fled their homes Sunday as strong winds pushed a forest fire to within kilometres of their communities.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Residents of Seymourville, Hollow Water First Nation and Manigotagan - three small communities clustered on the east shore of Lake Winnipeg - were told to leave their homes late Saturday evening, said Bob Buck of Manitoba Natural Resources.</p><p>-BODY- Unseasonably warm temperatures up to 26 C and winds gusting up to 70 kilometres per hour pushed the blaze to within four kilometres of the communities, about 150 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>Residents went to Bissett, a town about 40 kilometres east of the evacuated area.</p><p>"Everything happened so fast that everyone's minds are mixed up,'' said a woman from Manigotagan who would only give her name as Brenda.</p><p>"My ten-year-old was crying - we were totally in shock. It's not easy to leave your home.''</p><p>Fourteen people ended up crowding into Brenda's hotel room to spend the night.</p><p>"Everybody's settling in,'' Marlene Wynne said Sunday as she worked the cash register at Wynne's Place, a general store in Bissett.</p><p>"We got more people coming here than actually live here,'' she said.</p><p>Residents were put up at the community hall, school and the town's hotel, said Diana Soroka of Manitoba Emergency Management Organization.</p><p>Another 100 went to Lac du Bonnet, where they will stay at the local Legion hall, she added.</p><p>About 100 left Bissett to stay with family in Winnipeg and other places, Soroka said.</p><p>Buck said the fire - which started Saturday - had grown to 26 kilometres long and two kilometres wide by Sunday. The fire likely was caused by man, he added.</p><p>About 500 firefighters, 30 helicopters and five water bombers were battling the blaze.</p><p>A forest fire also destroyed four homes Saturday in St. Theresa Point, a remote, fly-in community about 400 kilometres northeast of Winnipeg.</p><p>Buck said the fire hazard is extreme in most of Manitoba's forested areas. Temperatures and winds are forecast to drop over the next few days, which will help the crews out fighting the fire, Buck said.</p><p>"But it doesn't look like much rain is coming with it,'' Buck added.</p><p>There were 64 fires burning in Manitoba on Sunday. Twenty new fires started Saturday, all man-made. There is a ban on open fires across the province.</p><p>In Ontario, forest fires almost forced the evacuation of 1,000 people from the town of Temagami Sunday.</p><p>Firefighters tamed the flames that raced across tree tops less than two kilometres from the town 130 kilometres north of Northbay</p><p>The fire, which was about 10 hectares in size when it started about 4 p.m., grew to more than 60 hectares in four hours.</p><p>At one point the fire edged within 100 metres of a marina before a water bomber dropped a load on the flames.</p><p>"I've never seen anything like it. There were red and orange flames a half mile up in the sky,'' said Temagami Mayor Wayne Adair.</p><p>The fire prompted Ontario Provincial Police to close Highway 11 near Temagami for several hours. (Winnipeg Free Press-North Bay Nugget)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4NS0-N6Y0-TX4V-K3DG-00000-00Forest fire crews train to help for anticipated B.C. flood emergencies2007-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSForest fire crews train to help for anticipated B.C. flood emergenciesFRANK PEEBLESCP

PRINCE GEORGE, B.C. (CP) _ Forest firefighters in British Columbia are being trained for the first time to help in flood emergencies.

Rescue Canada instructor Larry Obst says the logic is simple _ flooded places aren't likely to experiencing forest fires at the same time.

''Whoever came up with the idea, I'm impressed," said Obst, who was training forest workers in river safety Thursday on the Nechako River near Prince George, B.C.

''I think it's a good idea. What happens is, forestry crews already have the transportation and communication infrastructures to deal with emergencies,'' he said. ''The only thing different is instead of fires they will be dealing with flooding.''

In addition to the swift water rescue instructions from Obst, the forestry workers also got a combination of theory and practical training in sandbagging and dike building

The B.C. Forests Ministry said 240 firefighters are being trained for flood work, all members of the elite Initial Attack crews.

The communities of Kamloops, Castlegar, Williams Lake, Errigton, Smithers and Prince George are the first in the province to get the extra training.

The Provincial Emergency Program has them as an unprecedented resource in the event of flooding: a workforce of fit, capable, emergency-hardened specialists.

Obst said ''it gives them an awareness about what the hazards are near rivers (and) how do you save one of your teammates.''

''Flooding is going to happen,'' he said. ''The weather will dictate how much, but we fully expect it is going to happen to some extent this spring.''

urn:contentItem:55YN-XJW1-DYRH-B25X-00000-00Canadian Forces Provide 700 Forest Fire Evacuees with Food and Lodging at CFB Goose Bay2012-06-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCanadian Forces Provide 700 Forest Fire Evacuees with Food and Lodging at CFB Goose Bay

CFB GOOSE BAY, NEWFOUNDLAND AND LABRADOR--(Marketwire - June 24, 2012) - As of today, approximately 700 residents from the communities of North West River and Sheshatshiu in Newfoundland and Labrador have been evacuated to Canadian Forces Base (CFB) Goose Bay (5 Wing) as forest fires continue to encroach on the region's communities.

Today's action follows the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador's evacuation order, issued yesterday evening, and their formal request, through Public Safety Canada, for food and lodging for evacuees. Canadian Forces personnel have acted swiftly to meet the needs of the evacuated residents.

"The men and women of the Canadian Forces are dedicated to the safety and welfare of their fellow Canadians, bringing relief to those most affected by these wildfires," said the Honourable Peter MacKay, Minister of National Defence. "I am proud of the great work they do alongside provincial and municipal partners to support, in every way, those who face uncertainty and distress from all natural disasters."

The Canadian Forces (CF) provide assistance to civil authorities in a manner that complements other federal, provincial and municipal resources, in areas where their capabilities can effectively contribute to the overall relief effort. The Canadian Forces will continue to closely monitor the situation in conjunction with partner agencies, and will be prepared to provide additional assistance if and when called upon.

"The CF are committed to assisting our Whole-of-Government partners when a request for CF assistance is authorized," said Lieutenant-General Walter Semianiw, Commander Canada Command. "We will work closely with our partners to provide the appropriate CF capabilities to help resolve this crisis."

Canada Command's Joint Task Force Atlantic and CFB Goose Bay are working closely with the lead provincial agency, Fire and Emergency Services Newfoundland.

Canada Command directs and oversees domestic CF operations, bringing unique military capabilities to assist civil authority during natural disasters such as spring floods and forest fires, as well as supporting special events such as Royal Visits, and defending against threats to the safety and security of our citizens.

urn:contentItem:5T4H-V911-JDH3-G272-00000-00Evacuation alert lifted at Waterton Lakes National Park2018-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCALGARYEvacuation alert lifted at Waterton Lakes National ParkEvan Radford

<img src="https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/calgary/2018/08/27/evacuation-alert-lifted-at-waterton-lakes-national-park/waterton2018.jpg"/><br/>CALGARY-Thanks to some recent rain, Parks Canada has lifted an evacuation alert for the Waterton Lakes National Park, the federal agency announced Monday morning.A news update from Parks Canada says that the rain "suppressed the Boundary Wildfire in Glacier National Park, U.S.A. enough for Parks Canada to lift the alert. The evacuation alert was issued late Thursday night by Parks Canada; it didn't require park users or residents to immediately leave, but required them to prepare for an evacuation order if issued.Waterton is located just across the border from Montana's Glacier National Park.

World-renowned for its scenery and outdoor activities, it was devastated by fire just last year, when a forest fire torched an estimated 38 per cent of the park.The Boundary wildfire is still active, according to Parks Canada, measuring approximately 860 hectares in size. "We continue to work closely with Glacier National Park and other partner agencies to manage the wildfire, and protect key infrastructure and resources," the agency said in its update.<span class="endnote_contrib">Evan Radford is a reporter/photographer for StarMetro Calgary. Follow him on Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/EvanRadford">@EvanRadford</a></span>

urn:contentItem:3WG2-07N0-00H1-R4TC-00000-00<published>1988-05-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. A14</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Whitedog band set to go as massive forest fire nears</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>(CP-SPECIAL)</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>KENORA, Ontario</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>KENORA (CP-Special) - Public school buses and drivers stood by last night, ready to move out 950 residents of the remote Whitedog Indian reserve as a massive forest fire, fanned by southerly winds, threatened their community.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fire almost doubled in size from 4 p.m. to 8.30 p.m. as it moved north from Sherwood Lake, west of Kenora, to Malachi Lake, where at least five and maybe 10 cottages were destroyed.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Whitedog Reserve is just five kilometres (three miles) north of Malachi, said Dave Stepanik, fire prevention officer for the Kenora District.</p><p>"The evacuation of Whitedog started and then was stopped. There was too much smoke to ensure that the people would be better off on the buses," Stepanik said. "All it takes is a phone call and the evacuation is back on."</p><p>Prime timber</p><p>The buses are leased by the Kenora Board of Eduction, which means that a few students had to walk home yesterday, he added.</p><p>Dennis Howard, a spokesman for the Kenora office of the natural resources ministry, said the head of the fire, whipped by the gusting winds, was continuing to move through prime timber area and was burning out of control on both its east and west sides.</p><p>The fire, called Kenora 14 because it is the 14th fire of the season in the district, is four kilometres (2.5 miles) wide and 38 kilometres (23.5 miles) long.</p><p>The evacuation had been ordered as the fire pushed to within 16 kilometres (10 miles) of the reserve.</p><p>Emergency declared</p><p>About 70 people had already been moved from the communities of Malachi, Ottermere and Sherwood Lake, he said.</p><p>About 65 cottagers were taken out over the weekend and a fire near Fort Frances burned down a barn and killed nine head of cattle, a ministry official said.</p><p>Natural Resources Minister Vince Kerrio yesterday declared an emergency area covering about 1,500 square kilometres affected or threatened by the blaze.</p><p>The order, which permits any measures to be taken to suppress the fire or ensure the safety of residents, will remain in effect until next Monday, unless conditions improve.</p><p>Kerrio also declared the whole Northwestern corner of the province a restricted fire area, which prohibits any open campfires, even for warmth or cooking.</p><p>Water evaporating</p><p>"It's a war, and we hope we're winning in some areas," said ministry spokesman Dennis Wilson.</p><p>"What we're trying to do now is protect areas along the outside perimeter of the fire where there are cottages."</p><p>Wilson said the fire was so hot that much of the water being dropped from planes was evaporating before it hit the ground.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5XVT-TX71-JCF0-K0NH-00000-00Australian Wildfires2019-12-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCTV NATIONAL NEWS23:00:00 ETOMAR SACHEDINAAustralian Wildfires

OMAR SACHEDINA: Thousands have also been forced to flee their homes in Australia where deadly and destructive wildfires have burned an area roughly the size of Nova Scotia. Today crews raced to contain the flames before a heat wave hits this weekend. CTV's Janet Dirks has the latest.

JANET DIRKS (Reporter): This is the terror of escaping the fire's grip.

DANIELLA MCDERMID: Everywhere else was black and burned.

DIRKS: Daniella MacDiarmid's car flipped on its side as she tried to flee an out-of-control bushfire. She managed to get out, but her dog was trapped inside.

MCDERMID: So I had to get back into the car to smash the window out a bit more to grab him out to come out the window because I couldn't have left him in the car. I could see the back of the car on fire.

DIRKS: Hers was a story of survival in a fire season where at least nine people have been killed, more than 950 homes destroyed, and a staggering toll for wildlife as well. Nearly a third of the koalas in New South Wales are dead, unable to move fast enough to get away from fire. Ecologists fear nearly 500 million animals have perished since the fires began in September. Today, in what was considered mild weather before a heat wave returns, crews were on the ground shoring up protection.

UNIDENTIFIED MAN: We're just putting in a back burn containment line to try and prevent the fire from heading towards the coastal villages.

DIRKS: Canada has more than 50 firefighters in Australia, another three dozen on the way from across the country.

STEPHEN TULLE (Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre Duty Officer): They're performing roles in operations, in planning, logistics, aviation, and fire behaviour analysts.

DIRKS: Morgan Kehr has been in Sydney since December 5th from Edmonton.

MORGAN KEHR (Senior Canadian Agency Representative): The basics of fighting fire are the same. What makes it different here is the weather, the temperatures, and the fuels, and the vegetation. The rates of spread are pretty incredible at times here, especially in 40 degree weather, so that takes a little adjustment to stay ahead of a fire.

DIRKS: The Canadians in Australia are on 38-day stretches, and say the reception they've been getting has been extremely welcoming in this crisis. Omar.

SACHEDINA: All right, Janet. Thank you.

urn:contentItem:4700-NWK0-01G6-84WM-00000-00<published>1998-05-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Ont-Forest-Fire ; Restricted fire zone reduced</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>THUNDER BAY, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>THUNDER BAY, Ont. (CP) - Just in time for a long weekend of camping and fishing, the area's restricted fire zone has been reduced to a mere fraction of its former size.</p><p>Previously covering almost all of northwestern Ontario, the zone now only applies to Quetico Park and a chunk of land including Thunder Bay and an area just north of the city, bordering Lake Nipigon.</p><p>"We don't want to impose unnecessary restrictions in areas we believe we won't have problems with fire,'' Mitch Miller, a fire information officer, said Wednesday.</p><p>"People will be going to their camps and may want to be doing some cleanup.''</p><p>A restricted fire zone means all open fires, including campfires and garbage burning, are banned.</p><p>Meanwhile, rain has only helped bring down the fire hazard in some areas.</p><p>The largest fire in the area, covering 264 square kilometres of forest near Thunder Bay west of Lake Nipigon got just 1.4 millimetres of rain Tuesday. "That's not going to go too far,'' said Miller.</p><p>He said people travelling in the Upsala, Lac des Milles Lacs and Northern Light Lake areas should be especially careful this weekend.</p><p>"These are areas where lots of people will be fishing,'' he said. "I'd like to caution people because the area is still very dry.''</p><p>One fire started Wednesday when flames jumped the trench of a dump 30 kilometres southwest of Thunder Bay, said Miller. (Thunder Bay Chronicle-Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4PN1-7YK0-TX4V-K0JP-00000-00Forest fire season nearly over but B.C. minister urges campers to be careful2007-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSForest fire season nearly over but B.C. minister urges campers to be carefulKATE SKYECP

TRAIL, B.C. (CP) _ Forests Minister Rich Coleman says although fall is around the corner, B.C. forests are still susceptible to fire.

''Please be extremely careful with campfires, and ensure they are fully extinguished before you leave because they can continue to smoulder and re-ignite if conditions are right,'' Coleman said.

So far this year, there have been 415 fires in the Southeast Fire Centre, 80 of which were caused by humans. The centre also reported 82 abandoned campfires, nine of which had escaped from their fire pits.

And while small, controlled campfires are now permitted, all other open fires, as well as the use of fireworks and burning barrels, remain banned throughout the area.

''People still need to check with their municipalities and regional districts to find out if there are any other campfire bans in their area,'' said fire information officer Karlie Shaughnessy.

The Pend d'Oreille fire near Trail is 97 per cent contained.

Shaughnessy said the cause of the fire, which continues to be the largest in the province, is still under investigation, she said.

To date, the Southeast Fire Centre has not received any information that there were any people in the area when the fire started on Aug. 11.

While cooler temperatures and intermittent rain have improved fire conditions, the fire danger remains moderate to high in the southern portions of the Southeast Fire Centre.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Primrose-Fire ; Forest fire fight gets boost</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WHITEHORSE</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>WHITEHORSE (CP) - Another fire management team is being brought in from Ontario to oversee the renewed fight against a 4,000-hectare blaze near Primrose Lake.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Also, another 30 Ontario firefighters and 20 British Columbia firefighters are being imported to staff fires and allow the Yukon's initial attack crews to remain in their initial attack roles.</p><p>"We just want to be able to control that a little bit better, and resourcing up is a good idea,'' Rod Raycroft, communications officer with the Department of Northern Affairs, said Tuesday.</p><p>There are already 40 Ontario firefighters among the 110 firefighting staff members on the 1,700-hectare fire in the Haines Junction area.</p><p>As well, a new lightning-caused blaze in the Indian River area near Dawson City has grown substantially since Sunday.</p><p>Fire management is now assessing whether the Indian River fire should be put under the direction of another fire management team, Raycroft said.</p><p>To date, fire suppression costs in the Yukon have hit an estimated $1.2 million, compared to last years total cost of $767,000.</p><p>Suppression costs do not include wages for season and full-time staff, but do include items like the cost of hiring additional firefighting staff, Raycroft said.</p><p>The Yukon's two largest fires estimated recently at 9,600 and 13,000 hectares are burning in an observation zone southwest of Dawson, between the Yukon River and the border with Alaska.</p><p>(Whitehorse Star)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5T2M-38X1-F105-60B3-00000-00Letter: Attack fires faster2018-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisOPINIONLetter: Attack fires faster

It is time the B.C. Wildfire Service management and the minister responsible be called out for their limp-wristed approach to fighting forest fires.

They are jeopardizing our properties, our health, our lives and the environment with their lack of initial response.

They are so overly safety conscious, they are dysfunctional. Is it a risky job?

Sure it is, but a calculated risk.

Not attacking a fire for fear of injury is the same as saying you don't want your police force to attend robberies as they may get hurt.

It is your job!

A forest fire is an emergency and WorkSafeBC needs to curtail their enthusiasm for rules so first responders can function. BC Wildfire Services has little or no pre-organization to determine local assets, no night fighting capability and limited initial attack assets.

The best time to fight fire is when it is 0.1 of a hectare and not 100 ha. or larger. Costs go up dramatically when fire size increases.

We have a fire in the Keremeos area that was started by lightning on July 18.

There was no ground action prior to July 30, a response time of 12 days. Now they have a major fire on their hands caused by their own inaction. Evacuating people from their homes is not a fire plan of attack!

Gordon Plews, Keremeos
