urn:contentItem:3X1S-W7T0-00RJ-F538-00000-00<published>1998-08-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><broadcastInfo><show><showName>CTV NATIONAL NEWS</showName></show><newsAnchors>LLOYD ROBERTSON</newsAnchors></broadcastInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A BC town vows to pick up the pieces after a ferocious forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>LLOYD ROBERTSON: There is devastation and tragedy in fire<br/>ravaged British Columbia tonight. An evacuation order has been<br/>lifted in the hard hit community of Salmon Arm and dozens of<br/>families are coming home to charred ruins. CTV's Al Sweeney has the<br/>heartbreaking story of the people who've lost everything to the<br/>flames.</p><p>AL SWEENEY [Reporter]: This used to be home for Evelyn Scholzen<br/>and her family.</p><p>EVELYN SCHOLZEN [Resident]: Oh it was beautiful. I had the nicest<br/>house ever and I had the most beautiful yard you've ever seen.</p><p>SWEENEY: But now there's virtually nothing left. And even fire<br/>insurance is not enough.</p><p>SCHOLZEN: I've lost everything. I mean look at it.</p><p>ABBY-LEIGH SCHOLZEN [Resident]: That's my bed right there.</p><p>SWEENEY: And the kids have learned what it means to lose just<br/>about everything.</p><p>ABBY-LEIGH SCHOLZEN: I have one picture, I have a change of<br/>clothes and I have a couple of little nick knack things like this.<br/>This is left over. I found it in my room.</p><p>SWEENEY: The Scholzen home is on Branch Flower Road near Salmon<br/>Arm where house after house was wiped out when a forest fire came<br/>roaring down this valley.</p><p>KEN OVINGTON [Resident]: We lived here. We enjoyed it here.</p><p>SWEENEY: Ken Ovington is trying to figure out why it destroyed<br/>the home that he and his wife lived for 18 years.</p><p>OVINGTON: I had a sprinkler on the roof. I had metal siding. And<br/>I just can't understand why that house went and that one, well that<br/>one was drenched.</p><p>SWEENEY: Why the fire went right past other houses.</p><p>OVINGTON: Fire crews are still struggling in the mountains<br/>overlooking Branch Flower Road with a monster fire that now covers<br/>4,400 hectares.</p><p>ROY BENSON [Fire Boss]: This certainly was the most extreme fire<br/>behaviour that I have witnessed.</p><p>SWEENEY: And the BC forest service is defending itself from an<br/>angry backlash by saying it did everything it could to fight the<br/>blaze before high winds turned it into one of the worst fires<br/>they've ever seen. Despite the fire, Ken Ovington is resilient<br/>enough at the age of 74 to put his life back together.</p><p>OVINGTON: Pull up your socks and carry on. What, there's no point<br/>in laying down and crying about it is there?</p><p>SWEENEY: But for others, like a thirteen year old girl, it's not<br/>so easy.</p><p>ABBY-LEIGH SCHOLZEN: Terrible.</p><p>SWEENEY: Al Sweeney, CTV News, Salmon Arm, BC.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3X1S-W7T0-00RJ-F538-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">211506</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-26</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="403"/><timeReceived>23:00:00 - urn:contentItem:4GWP-MTD0-01G6-93B1-00000-00<published>2005-08-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Heavy smoke from forest fire spurs Fairbanks to open breathing respite centre</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FAIRBANKS, Alaska (AP) _ Heavy smoke from forest fires descended on the Fairbanks, prompting officials to open a respite breathing centre at Fairbanks Memorial Hospital.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The air was so thick with particulate Monday that machinery run by the Fairbanks North Star Borough could not keep up.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AP</p></bodyText></section><p>Health officials advised residents to remain inside, keep doors and windows closed and avoid strenuous activity until the air begins to clear.</p><p>"We're in a hazardous situation,'' said Dave Tyler, borough director of emergency operations.</p><p>Anyone with health conditions, breathing problems or the need for a breath of fresh air was welcome to the hospital's respite centre, officials said. They also suggested taking a breathing break at the borough's main library.</p><p>The National Weather Service forecast cooler, wetter weather with some showers and a wind change.</p><p>"The winds are changing, but no matter what direction they blow from, there's going to be smoke around,'' said assistant forecaster Ron Stuvek said. "Until we get a 24- or 36-hour rain event, it's just not going to change at all.''</p><p>Stuvek said the dense smoke came from the Beaver Creek Fire, which has hampered traffic on the Dalton Highway. A similar cloud blew into the area Saturday but did not produce the particulate levels measured Monday.</p><p>The Alaska Interagency Co-ordination Centre reported that firefighters were working 15 of 111 fires burning around the state.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20050816CPCPD9760</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4GWP-MTD0-01G6-93B1-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="236"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2005 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="16" month="08" year="2005"><dateText>August 16, 2005 Tuesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; urn:contentItem:50WG-VPB1-DYTJ-14J5-00000-00Alerts and campfire bans lifted as cooler weather brings forest fire relief2010-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSAlerts and campfire bans lifted as cooler weather brings forest fire reliefCP

VANCOUVER _ Cooler weather has changed the tune just a week after B.C.'s forest minister was sounding a warning of potentially dire consequences as wind whipped up forest fires in the province.

Several evacuation alerts have been rescinded and damp and cooler weather has even allowed officials to lift a campfire ban in limited parts of the coastal fire district and for all of the northwest and Prince George districts.

But while this fire season hasn't been as expensive to fight or as destructive to homes, more than twice the normal amount of forest has gone up in flames.

''We're more than double our 10-year average in terms of hectares burned,'' said provincial fire information officer Alyson Couch.

Just over 3,000 square kilometres went up in a matter of weeks. That's more than half the size of Prince Edward Island.

Just three evacuation alerts remain for residents where fires are burning near their homes, down from more than a dozen at the peak this season.

While Couch said there were more evacuation alerts and orders issued this year than last, many more people were evacuated during the 2009 fire season because the fires were closer to larger centres including in the Okanagan and Lillooet, B.C.

''We count our blessings where we can, but the fires certainly did impact a lot of people,'' she said referring to the high number of evacuation alerts this year.

The government spent $400 million last year fighting the fires compared to more than $165 million this year.

But some of the fires are massive and Couch said they may simply monitor the fire until the snow falls.

''When they cover a large area and the behaviour has calmed down a bit, we can go in and mop them up, but they might not get completely put out until the snow falls.''

While the job is easier now with the cooler weather and the fire behaviour isn't as aggressive as it was just a week ago, Couch said there is still a lot of work to do before the fire season is considered officially over.

urn:contentItem:5WNM-98D1-F103-32RM-00000-00All wood harvesting stopped in hot, dry North Cowichan forest reserve2019-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSAll wood harvesting stopped in hot, dry North Cowichan forest reserve

Given the current hot and dry conditions, North Cowichan is shutting down all wood harvesting activities in its municipal forest reserve at the end of the day today (Friday, July 26).

A statement from the municipality said North Cowichan has been monitoring the fire hazard ratings and weather conditions diligently during the blowdown salvage activities in the forest reserve and made the decision to stop operations on July 25.

The halt in operations will continue until the fall, with the exception of some trucking of roadside wood next week.

RELATED: Slow start to B.C. wildfire season saves province money

The statement said the decision has nothing to do with the excavator fire on Maple Mountain on July 24 that saw volunteer firefighters from Crofton and Maple Bay halls racing to the mountain around noon.

Crews were met at the gate at the bottom of Maple Mountain Park Road and guided up the M100 trail and then left onto a bumpy side trail to find a fully involved excavator fire.

The flames had spread into nearby foliage.

RELATED: Firefighters putting out hotspots at suspected human-caused wildfire near Sayward

It was a tricky situation for firefighters to juggle their water tenders on the narrow trails but they quickly got foam and water onto the flames.

The statement said the fire was completely extinguished within 30 minutes, and the excavator, which was cleaning up blowdown and debris along the roadside on the mountain, is being monitored to ensure there are no further flare ups.

The fire is still under investigation.

"The decision to halt operations was not due to this equipment fire," the statement said.

"Although it is generally uncommon, events such as this do occur from time to time, and contractors are required to have fire suppression equipment on site to contain any fires until the fire department arrives, which occurred yesterday."

Maple Mountain was the site of a major forest fire in August 2018. Seven fire departments and the BC Wildfire Service battled the 2018 blaze, and residents of the area were put on evacuation alert for three days.

urn:contentItem:5T0P-DK71-JDH3-G146-00000-00Young campers wash cars to help Parry Sound 33 firefighters2018-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYPg. 1Young campers wash cars to help Parry Sound 33 firefighters

PARRY SOUND - Camp George partnered with the Seguin Fire Department for a fundraising car wash for Parry Sound 33 firefighters.

Over the course of two car washes at the Orrville Community Centre, most recently on Friday, Aug. 3, over $560 was raised through a pay-what-you-can system. That was then donated to Parry Sound Sobeys to benefit the firefighters working on the Key River forest fire known as Parry Sound 33.

Parry Sound Sobeys is filling food orders for those working to contain and douse the fire that's been burning since July 18, has grown to 11,362 hectares and remains out of control.

"In the past we've raised money for the (Seguin) volunteer fire department, we're trying to give to the community ... with the Parry Sound 33 fire that was definitely one of the reasons we did get so many cars coming this time that we wanted to direct efforts to Sobeys' efforts," said Camp George director Jeff Rose.

Since the first packing of supplies by about 200 volunteers on Saturday, July 28, volunteers continue to act as personal shoppers to fill firefighters' grocery list each morning. From the store, the coolers and boxes are taken to the command centre in Britt and then taken into the fire area by helicopters.

urn:contentItem:50WG-HHW1-JCBG-94XF-00000-00Alerts and campfire bans lifted as cooler weather brings forest fire relief2010-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisWESTERN GENERAL NEWSAlerts and campfire bans lifted as cooler weather brings forest fire reliefCP

VANCOUVER _ Cooler weather has changed the tune just a week after B.C.'s forest minister was sounding a warning of potentially dire consequences as wind whipped up forest fires in the province.

Several evacuation alerts have been rescinded and damp and cooler weather has even allowed officials to lift a campfire ban in limited parts of the coastal fire district and for all of the northwest and Prince George districts.

But while this fire season hasn't been as expensive to fight or as destructive to homes, more than twice the normal amount of forest has gone up in flames.

''We're more than double our 10-year average in terms of hectares burned,'' said provincial fire information officer Alyson Couch.

Just over 3,000 square kilometres went up in a matter of weeks. That's more than half the size of Prince Edward Island.

Just three evacuation alerts remain for residents where fires are burning near their homes, down from more than a dozen at the peak this season.

While Couch said there were more evacuation alerts and orders issued this year than last, many more people were evacuated during the 2009 fire season because the fires were closer to larger centres including in the Okanagan and Lillooet, B.C.

''We count our blessings where we can, but the fires certainly did impact a lot of people,'' she said referring to the high number of evacuation alerts this year.

The government spent $400 million last year fighting the fires compared to more than $165 million this year.

But some of the fires are massive and Couch said they may simply monitor the fire until the snow falls.

''When they cover a large area and the behaviour has calmed down a bit, we can go in and mop them up, but they might not get completely put out until the snow falls.''

While the job is easier now with the cooler weather and the fire behaviour isn't as aggressive as it was just a week ago, Couch said there is still a lot of work to do before the fire season is considered officially over.

urn:contentItem:5T0X-C0B1-F105-64HM-00000-00Young campers wash cars to help Parry Sound 33 firefighters2018-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYPg. 1Young campers wash cars to help Parry Sound 33 firefighters

PARRY SOUND - Camp George partnered with the Seguin Fire Department for a fundraising car wash for Parry Sound 33 firefighters.

Over the course of two car washes at the Orrville Community Centre, most recently on Friday, Aug. 3, over $560 was raised through a pay-what-you-can system. That was then donated to Parry Sound Sobeys to benefit the firefighters working on the Key River forest fire known as Parry Sound 33.

Parry Sound Sobeys is filling food orders for those working to contain and douse the fire that's been burning since July 18, has grown to 11,362 hectares and remains out of control.

"In the past we've raised money for the (Seguin) volunteer fire department, we're trying to give to the community ... with the Parry Sound 33 fire that was definitely one of the reasons we did get so many cars coming this time that we wanted to direct efforts to Sobeys' efforts," said Camp George director Jeff Rose.

Since the first packing of supplies by about 200 volunteers on Saturday, July 28, volunteers continue to act as personal shoppers to fill firefighters' grocery list each morning. From the store, the coolers and boxes are taken to the command centre in Britt and then taken into the fire area by helicopters.

urn:contentItem:7W8G-S3B1-2R6R-52VK-00000-00Forest fire evacuation order lifted for 1,000 people near Vernon, B.C.2009-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSForest fire evacuation order lifted for 1,000 people near Vernon, B.C.CP

VERNON, B.C. _ A week after they were chased out of their homes by a growing wildfire, residents who live along British Columbia's Okanagan Lake are being allowed back home.

An evacuation order has been lifted for 1,000 who live along the heavily forested area of Fintry, B.C., just across the lake from Vernon.

Residents have been told they'll be allowed to go home at 8 a.m. Thursday, with the warning that they remain on evacuation alert and should be prepared to leave again with little notice.

But 13 remaining residents in the Fintry High Farms area remain on evacuation order. They were closest to the fire and among the first to be ordered out last week.

''The head of the fire is still out of control,'' fire information officer Tim Neal said. ''We've got containment lines in front of it.''

Neal said the fire is 85 per cent contained, surrounded by 36 kilometres of fire guards, but hot, dry weather is forecast to continue.

Winds have been mercifully light and in fact changed direction Wednesday and pushed the fire back on itself, Neal said.

Fire crews plan to continue burning off unburned fuel between the fire guard and the perimeter of the fire, he said.

At the peak of the Terrace Mountain fire 2,200 residents were forced out on July 23, when the fire doubled in size and the flames jumped along the tops of the trees.

About 1,200 residents were allowed to return to their homes Saturday.

On the same day a water bomber fighting the fire crashed into Okanagan Lake.

Eyewitnesses said the planes landing gear was down. The pilot survived the crash with minor injuries.

The lifting of the evacuation order comes just two days after an evacuation alert for 17,000 people was lifted in the West Kelowna area, where a wildfire destroyed three houses and a mobile home before being contained.

Meanwhile, more than 500 people have been placed on evacuation alert west of Lillooet, were a 1,500-hectare, lightning-caused fire continues to advance on the communities of Seton Portage and Shalath.

urn:contentItem:5GD8-HVX1-JC8F-M1YX-00000-00Cameco Provides an Update on Saskatchewan Forest Fire Situation2015-07-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisCameco Provides an Update on Saskatchewan Forest Fire Situation

SASKATOON, SASKATCHEWAN--(Marketwired - July 9, 2015) -

ALL AMOUNTS ARE STATED IN CDN $ (UNLESS NOTED)

Cameco (TSX:CCO)(NYSE:CCJ) announced today that production at its McArthur River, Key Lake, Cigar Lake and Rabbit Lake uranium operations in the Athabasca Basin has not been interrupted by forest fires in northern Saskatchewan.

Cameco has implemented additional measures to protect the health and safety of people and the environment at its facilities and is assisting northern communities in fighting the fires and supporting evacuees. None of Cameco's operations are directly threatened by the fires which are concentrated in north central Saskatchewan.

Road closures and flight restrictions at northern airstrips are creating logistical challenges to keep the operations supplied with essential materials and staffed. About half of the workforce at Cameco's Saskatchewan operations are residents of northern Saskatchewan and evacuations of workers and their families are creating additional challenges.

In order to keep non-essential traffic off the two hard-surface roads that connect its operations with southern Saskatchewan, Cameco voluntarily suspended shipments of packaged uranium from its milling facilities. The roads have been periodically closed due to poor visibility related to smoke and proximity to fire. Product is being safely stored and will be shipped once the fire situation improves.

Cameco expects to meet its 2015 production target of 25.3 to 26.3 million pounds and its 2015 sales target of 31 to 33 million pounds.

Profile

Cameco is one of the world's largest uranium producers, a significant supplier of conversion services and one of two Candu fuel manufacturers in Canada. Our competitive position is based on our controlling ownership of the world's largest high-grade reserves and low-cost operations. Our uranium products are used to generate clean electricity in nuclear power plants around the world. We also explore for uranium in the Americas, Australia and Asia. Our shares trade on the Toronto and New York stock exchanges. Our head office is in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Caution Regarding Forward-Looking Information and Statements

The statements that Cameco expects to meet its 2015 production target of 25.3 to 26.3 million pounds and its 2015 sales target of 31 to 33 million pounds are "forward-looking information" or "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of Canadian and U.S. securities laws. This information is based upon a number of assumptions that, while considered reasonable by management, are subject to significant uncertainties and contingencies. We have assumed that: the severe forest fires in northern Saskatchewan do not cause more extensive damage than currently expected or delay or disrupt production from our Saskatchewan mines and mills or the McClean Lake mill; our development, mining and production plans succeed; our expectations are met regarding the success of our jet boring mining method and the Cigar Lake deposit freezes as planned; modification and expansion of the McClean Lake mill are completed as planned and the mill is able to process Cigar Lake ore as expected; there is no material delay or disruption in our plans as a result of political instability, terrorism, government or political actions, ground movements, cave-ins, additional water inflows, a failure of seals or plugs used for previous water inflows, natural phenomena, delay in acquiring critical supplies or equipment, equipment failure, transportation disruptions or other causes; there are no labour disputes or shortages; contractors, equipment, operating parts, supplies, regulatory permits and approvals are obtained when needed; and that our mineral reserves estimate and the assumptions it is based on are reliable. This forward-looking information also involves known and unknown risks, uncertainties, and other factors that may cause actual results and developments to differ materially from those expressed or implied.

They include the risks: that the impact of the forest fires in northern Saskatchewan is more severe than expected, causing production delays or more extensive damage; that an unexpected geological, hydrological or underground condition or an additional water inflow delays or disrupts our plans; of political instability, terrorism, government or political actions, natural phenomena, labour disputes, equipment failure, transportation disruptions, delay in obtaining the required contractors, equipment, operating parts and supplies or other reasons cause a material delay or disruption in our plans; that our development, mining or production plans are delayed or do not succeed for any reason, including, in respect of Cigar Lake, technical difficulties with the jet boring mining method or freezing the deposit to meet production targets, or any difficulties with the McClean Lake mill modifications or expansion or milling of Cigar Lake ore; that our mineral reserves estimate is not reliable; and that our uranium suppliers fail to fulfill delivery commitments. Please also see our most recent annual information form, annual MD&A and quarterly MD&A for other risks and assumptions relevant to the forward-looking information in this news release. We are providing this forward-looking information to help you understand management's views regarding the impact of northern Saskatchewan forest fires on Cameco's 2015 production and sales targets and it may not be appropriate for other purposes. Cameco does not undertake any obligation to update or revise forward-looking information, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except to the extent legally required.

urn:contentItem:461J-Y8F0-01G6-9420-00000-00<published>2002-06-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire forces evacuation of reserve in west-central Alberta</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ROCKY MOUNTAIN HOUSE, Alta. (CP) _ A forest fire that forced about 85 people to flee their homes on the Sunchild reserve in west-central Alberta spread onto reserve land Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Flames were very close to at least six homes Friday evening, said Dan Lux of Alberta Sustainable Resource Development.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Crews worked into the night, desperatly trying to save the properties.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Water bombers were used until nightfall in the hopes of getting a bulldozer in to dig a guard around the homes.</p><p> Those six properties are the top priority,'' Lux said. They are not burning yet, but it is very close.''</p><p>Forestry staff spotted the fire from a lookout tower Thursday afternoon and residents were evacuated that night. It's suspected the fire was caused by lightning.</p><p>The fire was 15 square kilometres in size Friday evening, Lux said.</p><p>Homes are scattered throughout the reserve of 460 people. Residents in the southern portion were told to leave and other families were on two-hour evacuation alert.</p><p>The evacuated families went to the nearby town of Rocky Mountain House and were being put up in the arena.</p><p>Band councillor Paul Bigchild said the residents were not panicking.</p><p> We're more or less relaxed right now. Everybody wants to go home but they know the situation,'' he said.</p><p>Corey Redcalf, 21, who has young children, said he was glad everyone was safe. It was alarming to have the fire so close, he said.</p><p> I was going to stay on the reserve but everyone saw the smoke. I didn't know if everyone was going to get evacuated or not, and all of a sudden buses started coming by and people started coming around the house,'' he said about the order to pull out.</p><p>As Sunchild residents were being told to leave their community, people from Conklin in northeastern Alberta were returning to theirs after spending nearly two weeks in Fort McMurray.</p><p>The hamlet of 254 was evacuated when it was threatened by a massive blaze known as the House River fire, which covered about 2,800 square kilometres and was still out of control Friday.</p><p>It was burning five kilometres west of Conklin. The hamlet's residents remained on evacuation alert. At the other end of the fire, an evacuation alert was lifted for people living at Mariana Lake.</p><p>Until recently, firefighters had a difficult time containing the House River fire because of extreme fire conditions.</p><p> With the last couple of days that we've had this rain we've managed to get a handle on some of that, which has led us to believe that it would be safe right now for the Conklin residents to return,'' said Joe Prusak of Alberta Environment.</p><p>Prusak said firefighters have also ringed the community with a large number of fire guards, turning it into a virtual fortress.</p><p>Weather conditions were forecast to be favourable for the next couple of days with lower temperatures and higher relative humidities.</p><p>With more moisture in the air firefighters don't have to worry as much about the tops of trees burning and fire jumping from tree to tree, a volatile situation called crown fires.</p><p> The ground crews can get in and actually get a little bit of work done and really guard that perimeter,'' Prusak said.</p><p>Near Edmonton, a fire close to the town of Redwater _ which destroyed four homes last week _ was contained and being held Friday, but residents remained on evacuation alert.</p><p>Northern Saskatchewan has also been plagued by forest fires but cloudy, cool and wet weather was helping to calm the situation there as well.</p><p>Fire officials said blazes near the Alberta boundary at Loon Lake, Dore Lake, and Tobin Lake were not yet under control, but crews were able to contain them.</p><p>An evacuation alert for the community of Loon Lake was lifted. Evacuation orders for the Pine Cove resort north of Loon Lake and a nearby reserve were also lifted.</p><p>Fire danger ratings across the north were downgraded from extreme and ranged from high to moderate. On Friday the Saskatchewan government lifted its ban on open fires but urged people exercise caution.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:3W47-1G50-00H1-P550-00000-00<published>1998-08-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. A25</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire forces 150 from northern village Some residents of remote area refuse to accept airlift out</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>(CP)</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>TIMMINS</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>TIMMINS (CP) - About 150 people were forced from their remote Northern Ontario homes yesterday after a forest fire burned within a kilometre of the town of Peawanuk.</p><p nitf:lede="true">While forest fires in the Prairies and B.C. appeared to stabilize, two Hercules aircraft were called in to help airlift people from the community on Hudson Bay to Timmins - a 2 1/2-hour flight away.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Some 40 people refused to leave town, including the band chief, and decided to fight the flames instead.</p><p>It's expected it will take about three days for the area to clear.</p><p>"I'm thinking this fire is in good shape and could see . . . people being back in their community by the weekend," said Dan Johnson, the natural resources ministry fire technician called in to handle the fire.</p><p>Some 15 firefighters were still trying to get the fire under control yesterday.</p><p>"Crews are making excellent progress," said Johnson. "The weather and weather forecast has really assisted us in our effort."</p><p>Johnson said some nine millimetres of rain fell Wednesday night.</p><p>The fire spread to 100 hectares and crept to within a kilometre of the town on the Weenuska First Nation reserve when the acting chief declared an emergency.</p><p>Johnson said the fire was still within a kilometre of Peawanuk yesterday afternoon but felt there was no danger of it spreading further due to the direction of the winds.</p><p>The McIntyre Curling Club and Spruce Hill Manor in South Porcupine have been converted into shelter facilities.</p><p>Margaret Mack, a Peawanuk band council member, said many of the community's residents were unwilling to leave until it became obvious their lives were in danger.</p><p>Flames were visible to those in the community and the "smoke was so dense, you could barely breathe," she said. "We could only bring two bags each, enough for a change of clothes, medication and baby stuff."</p><p>Mack said this is the third time since 1986 that natural disaster has forced the evacuation of Peawanuk.</p><p>Massive ice flows forced people to leave their homes in the spring of 1997, and a flood destroyed most of the community in 1986.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">TSTAR1998</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7W6B-G530-Y958-F2KM-00000-0011,000 flee forest fire in Okanagan2009-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A0411,000 flee forest fire in OkanaganAt least 3 houses devoured by flames as officials urge diehards not to remain in evacuation zoneSunny DhillonThe Canadian PressKELOWNA, B.C.

The neighbours grabbed family photos and pets and fled, but Brante Farrell donned a gas mask and heavy overalls and turned on the lawn sprinklers.

Farrell said yesterday he feels quite safe defying the evacuation order that has sent 11,000 people in his Okanagan suburb fleeing from a wind-whipped wildfire that has razed at least three homes and destroyed other buildings.

"The danger has really seemed distant," Farrell, 25, said in a telephone interview from the estate he is house-sitting in the hills on the west side of Okanagan Lake, opposite Kelowna.

The fire broke out Saturday as the mercury hit 34C, following weeks of dry conditions.

"I know it could move in quickly, but I'm keeping a good ear on the radio and I've got people watching from the distance. They're going to phone me if they hear anything."

RCMP said there have been few evacuation refuseniks like Farrell. However, a frustrated B.C. Forests Minister Pat Bell had harsh words for anyone who thinks it's a good idea to stay in the evacuation zone.

"(It's) an absolutely boneheaded idea," Bell said yesterday. "This fire has the potential to be very volatile. If we see any sort of substantive winds, it can turn around and come up behind you and you will have no way out."

But Farrell said he's staying put, watching over the property while keeping an eye on what's happening in the nearby forests.

He's making sure the hedges are well watered and he keeps a torrent of water running down the exterior of the house.

"I have an excellent range of view here and I have a gas mask and heavy overalls and my truck is gassed up and pointed straight to the road. I could actually probably leave the house in about 30 seconds."

He said power was out at the house and the smell of smoke was everywhere.

In addition to the 11,000 residents ordered out, another 6,000 were placed on evacuation alert, according to Jeanne Rucker of the B.C. Forest Service.

It's unclear how long people will be out of their homes, but Rucker was slightly optimistic yesterday afternoon that the fire situation was looking "substantially better."

The winds had died somewhat and the fire was being pushed toward Okanagan Lake, she said.

"It's scary, you know," said Wilf Carey as he registered at the local evacuee centre. "We just did what we were told. We just picked up our belongings and got out."

Carey's house was among 6,500 homes deemed in danger.

Hotel rooms throughout Kelowna and surrounding Okanagan cities quickly booked up Saturday night, leaving no vacancies.

But Barb Richardson, a volunteer at the evacuee centre, said most people have been quite calm and understanding of the situation.

Temperatures were predicted to rise to 31C today and 34 tomorrow, and there is no rain in sight.

In 2003, lightning strikes triggered a fire across the lake in Kelowna that scorched 250 square kilometres, destroyed more than 200 homes and caused millions of dollars in property damage.

ANDY CLARK Reuters A huge forest fire glows at dawn in the hills on the west side of Okanagan Lake, across from Kelowna, last night. The blaze, which began Saturday, has forced the evacuation of 11,000 residents.

urn:contentItem:5TBK-XN71-F03R-N0J8-00000-00Huge blaze forces hundreds from homes in Tuscany2018-09-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisHuge blaze forces hundreds from homes in Tuscany

Sep 25, 2018( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) A vast forest fire has forced the evacuation of hundreds of people from their houses in Tuscany, with firefighters Tuesday battling to extinguish flames fanned by fierce winds.Around 600 hectares in total had been consumed by the blaze, chief Pisan firefighter Ugo D'Anna told a local television, adding that while it was now contained it would take some hours to put out.The fire was "almost certainly arson," he said.Two water-dropping planes and 80 firefighters, helped by 50 volunteers, were tackling the blaze, which broke out overnight Monday near Pisa in northern Italy, briefly threatening the towns of Calci, Montemagno and San Lorenzo e la Torre.Some 500 inhabitants were evacuated as olive trees burned in their groves and the sky across the area turned a deep orange, according to an AFP photographer at the scene.

On Tuesday the region's four firefighting helicopters were grounded to the strong winds.Tuscany's governor Enrico Rossi said evacuated locals would not be able to return for 24 hours while risk assessments were carried out."The firefighters were our angels. It was an apocalyptic scene and thankfully they saved us," one evacuee was reported as saying by Italian media."I really hope the blaze was carelessness because I can't bear to think it could have been such an evil act by such a twisted mind."

urn:contentItem:5XMX-55X1-JBVR-33VS-00000-0010 Things to Know for Today2019-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL10 Things to Know for Today10 Things to Know for TodayThe Associated Press

Your daily look at late-breaking news, upcoming events and the stories that will be talked about today:

1. WHAT CHANGES TO SEX-ABUSE LAWS COULD COST CATHOLIC CHURCH

The Associated Press finds that a wave of new laws in 15 states could result in at least 5,000 new cases against the church and more than $4 billion in payouts.

2. IMPEACHMENT INVITATION REJECTED

The White House has declared it will not participate in the first impeachment hearing before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.

3. BEIJING PUSHES BACK AGAINST WASHINGTON

China says it will suspend U.S. Navy visits to Hong Kong and sanction pro-democracy non-governmental organizations in retaliation for U.S. legislation supporting human rights in the semi-autonomous territory.

4. FOREST FIRE DANGER SPARKS INNOVATION

A new technology being tested by California utilities is aimed at diagnosing problems before they can cause power outages or spark wildfires.

5. CHINA'S COMPLICATED ENVIRONMENTAL RECORD

It's the top emitter of greenhouse gases and burns about half the coal used globally each year. But it's also the leading market for solar panels, wind turbines and electric vehicles, and manufactures most of the world's solar cells.

6. A CONCERT THAT TURNED TRAGIC, 40 YEARS LATER

Eleven people were killed in a frantic stampede of people trying to get into The Who's Dec. 3, 1979, Cincinnati concert. Three were teens from Finneytown, Ohio. Neither the city nor the band have forgotten.

7. A CHALLENGING DANCE FOR A VISA

Ballroom dance studio owners say the immigration clampdown has made it even more difficult to find qualified instructors, and it's hurting their businesses.

8. CAPTURING HISTORY BEFORE IT'S GONE

A group of U.S.-based scientists are rushing to document ancient indigenous sites along Puerto Rico's coastline that date back a couple thousand years and are threatened by rising sea levels.

9. LEBANESE WOMEN PUSH BACK AGAINST RELIGIOUS LAWS

Lebanon's many religious sects mean it has 15 sets of laws over such things as rules for marriage, divorce and child custody. Critics say it discriminates against women of all faiths, and recent protests have given them a platform.

10. MEASLES OUTBREAK DEVASTATES SAMOA

Most of the 53 people who have died during the epidemic on the South Pacific island have been babies and young infants, including 23 children aged less than 1 and 25 children between 1 and 4 years old.

urn:contentItem:4P8Y-W370-TX4V-K555-00000-00Northern Manitoba's forest fire situation serious: minister2007-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSNorthern Manitoba's forest fire situation serious: ministerTAMARA KINGCP

WINNIPEG (CP) _ Mother Nature isn't co-operating with efforts to stamp out dozens of forest fires in northern Manitoba that have displaced hundreds of people.

Conservation Minister Stan Struthers said that after a ''tough'' summer in 2006, this year's fires are the worst he's seen.

''This is the most serious of those four (summers) that I can speak for,'' said Struthers, fresh off a flight touring some of the province's fire hot spots.

An out-of-control fire burning less than three kilometres from Tadoule Lake practically cleared out the Sayisi Dene reserve.

Curtis Smith, executive director of the Manitoba Association of Native Fire Fighters, said only firefighters and key members of the band remained in the remote community, almost 1,000 kilometres from Winnipeg.

''With the smoke and fire danger, the community just wants to be safe,'' Smith said

About 60 more residents facing evacuation Thursday were scheduled to join more than 300 people in Brandon, Man., who had already been forced from their homes at Tadoule Lake.

At one point Thursday, Smith said a total of 772 people had been evacuated from various communities. However, by late afternoon more than 400 residents of South Indian Lake received word they could return to their homes.

''There's no threat to the community,'' said Smith, adding it could take two days to transport people back to South Indian Lake, about 725 kilometres north of Winnipeg.

Lightning strikes had sparked 12 new forest fires by Thursday morning, bringing the total number of fires burning to 60.

''This year it seems to be busy, but it just doesn't seem to end,'' said Gary Friesen, a supervisor with Manitoba Conservation's fire program.

''This is a bad year because of the dry conditions we've experienced in the northwest.''

When it came to precipitation this week, Mother Nature got it backwards. While northern Manitoba saw lightning storms, it missed the massive downpour that Winnipeg experienced Wednesday evening.

More than 500 firefighters, including crews from B.C. and Ontario, were battling roughly half of the 60 blazes.

Struthers noted firefighters have a difficult task on their hands, as they are forced to wear heavy protective gear and lug heavy hoses around during a week-long heatwave,

''Those are our heroes,'' he said. ''They're the people working hard to make sure other Manitobans are safe.''

urn:contentItem:5SWP-S491-JDH3-G3TD-00000-00Letter: Fed funding can be better spent2018-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisOPINIONLetter: Fed funding can be better spent

The Okanagan is again experiencing forest fires and as climate change gets worse we will face more and more of these events.

Unfortunately, it's pretty clear that climate change is not a priority for the federal Liberals or Conservatives. Last year B.C.'s worst fire season on record cost $563 million. Forest fighters worked 70 days and 65,000 people were displaced. But compare that to the $600 million Mr. Trudeau spent for a three-day meeting in Quebec for wealthy G7 world leaders. Or to the $1.1 billion the Harper Conservatives spent on a three-day G8/20 meeting in 2010. (People may recall the $50 million of that was siphoned off into MP Tony Clement's riding to build a gazebo. Conservative voters have rewarded this unethical behaviour by putting "Gazebo Tony" back into office ever since.)

When Liberal and Conservative politicians think it is appropriate to spend more on three-day meetings than what is spent on a record-breaking forest fire season I think they have lost touch. The 2 billion+ spent on two meetings could have been better spent on Canadian veterans, affordable housing for the homeless, modernizing a failing health care system, clean drinking water or child poverty.

I would rather my tax dollars go to help my fellow Canadians rather than to wine and dine the rich and powerful friends of Liberals and Conservatives.

B. Cousins

urn:contentItem:5SW2-VJ41-F105-63SX-00000-00Key River fire causes evacuation of two communities2018-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Key River fire causes evacuation of two communities

PARRY SOUND - The aggressive fire which caused the mandatory evacuation of Key River was at 1,900 hectares as of late last night.

The community of Key Harbour on the south side of the Key River; and residents of the municipality of Killarney for residents on the north side of the Key River south of French River Provincial Park) were evacuated.

Police and conservation officers facilitated the evacuation and safely guided all residents and members of the public out of the area. It has been confirmed that the fire, which had started on the south side of the Key River, has now also spread to the north side of the Key River, into French River Provincial Park, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services Northeast Region.

Increased fire behavior led to the closure of the TransCanada highway due to smoke from forest fires. There is a significant amount of smoke along Highway 69, south of Grundy Lake Provincial Park. Aerial fire suppression and ground crews are on site. It is expected that this 1,900 hectare fire will continue to create smoke in the days to come.

By the evening of July 20, there were 65 active forest fires across the Northeast, of these, 34 are not yet under control, 31 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were eight new fire starts in the region yesterday.

urn:contentItem:5TRF-WRF1-JDH1-C0RR-00000-00New book delves into local history2018-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENTNew book delves into local history

Books on local Okanagan Valley history are published every year. But a new history book is a little different, aimed at children and telling a local story.

Okanagan author Karen Autio wrote Growing Up in Wild Horse Canyon for kids aged aged 7 to 10. The book is illustrated by artist Loraine Kemp.

The book begins with a glossary and pronunciation guide of some common Syilx (Okanagan Nation) words, but the story itself begins in Wild Horse Canyon in 1780, describing traditional Syilx activities.

Years later, in 1811, comes the arrival of the first fur traders and the use of the Fur Brigade Trail. One illustration in the book accurately depicts the Brigade Lookout, part of Summerland's municipal park.

During the First World War, horses were in great demand and horses from Wild Horse Canyon were used for the war. Russia alone bought and shipped 1,400 B.C. horses. During the Second World War, Commando Bay was used to train Chinese-Canadian soldiers for the war in the Pacific.

The book later describes the creation of Okanagan Mountain Park and the massive forest fire of 2003. ending with the regrowth of vegetation in Wild Horse Canyon and the return of its wild horses.

The book also contains a section for teachers that provides a very detailed history of the area.

The Summerland Museum is hosting an evening for the public to celebrate the publication of Growing Up in Wild Horse Canyon on Nov. 19 at 6:30 p.m. The author and the illustrator will be in attendance to sign copies of their book. Refreshments will be provided.

urn:contentItem:4700-NWH0-01G6-840P-00000-00<published>1998-05-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AM-Ont-Forest-Fire ; Firefighters continue to battle blaze</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>THUNDER BAY, Ont.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>THUNDER BAY, Ont. (CP) - Firefighters aren't out of the woods yet even though the large fire west of Lake Nipigon hasn't grown in seven days.</p><p>Low lying smoke and large flames were making it difficult Sunday for crews to circle the fire with bulldozer lines and hoses, said Dave Jackson a spokesman with the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><p>"It's a huge task when you think about (the equivalent) of laying a hose line around the city of Thunder Bay,'' Jackson said.</p><p>The fire, 120 kilometres northeast of this city, stopped growing since it reached 250 square kilometres on May 4.</p><p>Jackson said forming a prevention circle around the fire is the first step to putting it out.</p><p>"It enables us to put out the spots around the fringe and then work toward the middle,'' he said.</p><p>Erratic fire behavior forced crews to pull back Saturday, forcing a delay of the scheduled burns until Sunday.</p><p>Jackson said crews should be able to prevent further spreading of the fire but warned of a high risk of new fires, given forecasters aren't calling for rain until Wednesday.</p><p>Ministry fire crews responded to eight new forest fires Sunday, bringing the total to 10 active fires in the region.</p><p>Three fires reported near Dryden, Ont., were sparked by train traffic through tinder dry land. (Thunder-Bay Chronicle-Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H0G-9JX0-01G6-94WJ-00000-00<published>2005-08-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Evacuation alert lifted as rain helps quell forest fire near Kelowna</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KELOWNA, B.C. (CP) _ An evacuation alert was lifted Monday after rain helped quell a potentially dangerous weekend fire near the suburb of Westbank.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Rose Valley fire erupted suddenly around 9 p.m. Saturday night in a park on a hillside overlooking a Westbank neighbourhood, forcing emergency officials to order more than 450 people out of their homes on short notice.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>They were allowed to return Sunday as fire crews got the upper hand over the 25-hectare blaze. But an evacuation alert was not formally lifted until Monday morning, said fire information officer Dale Bohjara.</p><p>"With the rain we received the fire is now considered 100 per cent contained,'' he said. "With that the local government has lifted the evacuation alert that was affecting the folks in the Rose Valley area.''</p><p>Bohjara said crews were in mop-up mode, jumping on the fire's remaining hot spots.</p><p>"We do have a fairly large number of people on the fire today, we actually still have approximately 75 people out there so they're making short work of a lot of these spots,'' he said.</p><p>Bohjara said the weather also co-operated Monday, with cool, cloudy conditions and the possibility of more rain.</p><p>The weekend fire brought back memories of the summer of 2003, when more than 30,000 people in the Kelowna area had to flee their homes as a fast-moving wildfire swept through forested neighbourhoods, destroying dozens of homes.</p><p>"In this immediate area in the central Okanagan, this rain will knock back the fire hazard for at least the short term,'' said Bohjara. "Then depending on what kind of weather we get, if we get more hot and dry, it could bounce back a bit.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20050829CPCPG4597</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4H0G-9JX0-01G6-94WJ-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="272"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2005 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="29" month="08" year="2005"><dateText>August 29, 2005 Monday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; urn:contentItem:46YX-VM20-01G6-82CR-00000-00<published>2001-05-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BC-Alta-Forest-Fire, Bgt ; EDM OUT EQQ; EDS: UPDATES with forestry plane crashing while fighting fires paras 7-10, FIXES typo para 5 to read thick'' not think'', UPDATES number of fires burning para 22; Member Photo Requested; INDEX: Health, Environment, Agriculture; HL:Alberta forest fire north of Edmonton continued to burn out of control Friday</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By John Cotter</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Steady north winds stoked a raging forest fire to more than twice its size Friday as officials scrambled to evacuate families from isolated homes south of a northern Alberta hamlet.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Conditions were so dry that trees and brush were literally exploding into flames as the fire grew to 100 square kilometres of bush and farmland near Chisholm, about 200 kilometres north of Edmonton, said Alberta fire office spokesman Rick Strickland.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- "The fuel is really dry and we are getting intense burning,'' he said. "When a fire gets this size, it creates its own winds.</p><p>"We have evacuated some people from the south-side residences in the area.''</p><p>Altogether 12 families - about 30 people - were ordered to leave their homes due to thick clouds of acrid smoke.</p><p>"There is a lot of smoke. If there is a wind shift, the fires could encroach the residences themselves.''</p><p>Meanwhile, a light aircraft that was helping fight fires crashed in a remote forest about 160 kilometres north of Slave Lake, Alta.</p><p>"We believe there's a plane down and it's under investigation,'' said RCMP Const. Steve Henson from the Red Earth Creek detachment.</p><p>The Cessna was carrying two people who were both killed, said the Search and Rescue Co-ordination Centre in Trenton, Ont.</p><p>Firefighters found the wreckage in the bush. It was not clear whether the plane was fighting the Chisholm fire or other blazes in northern Alberta.</p><p>Back near Chisholm, Doug and Maureen Schiller and their sister-in-law Rachel scrambled to gather their farm animals and keepsakes before leaving.</p><p>"I'm packing up wedding pictures, wedding albums, my husband's baby book, anything I can't replace,'' Rachel Schiller said as she watched the flames off in the distance.</p><p>"People are taking our cattle for us. And we don't even care where they go. We've had to move out 45 head and their calves.''</p><p>Farmer Elwin Whyte said the flames were shooting 30 metres in the air within a few kilometres from his wheat and barley operation as the fire leaped from treetop to treetop.</p><p>Whyte sent his wife and younger children to safety but stayed behind with an older son to dig trenches and water down outbuildings.</p><p>He said the situation was "pretty scary.''</p><p>"I was worried. You get quite excited.''</p><p>The fire broke out Wednesday near a CN rail line. The cause of the blaze was still under investigation.</p><p>The area is mainly wooded hills and farmland. Drought conditions and moderate winds have made it difficult to contain the fire.</p><p>Hundreds of gas wells are in the area, but they were shut down as a precaution before the flames got too close.</p><p>More than 160 firefighters and several helicopters were battling the blaze.</p><p>About two dozen fires were burning in the province Friday.</p><p>The dry conditions prompted the province to extend a ban on open fires from a line between Peace River and Lac la Biche in northern Alberta to points just above the U.S. border.</p><p>"The continued drying trend will result in a buildup of high to extreme forest fire hazard conditions,'' said a provincial release. "These conditions will increase the potential for out-of-control fires.''</p><p>So far this spring Alberta has received only trace amounts of moisture instead of normal rainfall levels of between 50 and 100 millimetres.</p><p>Major rivers south of northern Alberta are running at three-quarters to less than half of normal water levels.</p><p>The lack of moisture and a near record low mountain snowpack, coupled with a dry winter and two previous dry summers, have officials bracing for one of the worst agricultural droughts since the 1930s.</p><p>"Almost 90 per cent of the provincial agriculture area doesn't have enough soil moisture for annual cropping this year,'' said Alberta Agriculture spokesman Lloyd Andruchow.</p><p>"These conditions are threatening to impact what is a $7-billion primary agricultural industry in Alberta.''</p><p>The government is expected to announce additional drought support programs if the province doesn't receive significant rainfall by the end of June. (Edmonton Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:47T0-4T80-01G6-9101-00000-00<published>2003-01-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WESTERN GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Massive Alberta forest fire continues to burn after eight months</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FORT McMURRAY, Alta. (CP) _ One of the biggest fires in recent Alberta history continues to burn more than eight months after it began.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Scorching more than 2,380 square kilometres of forest since it ignited May 17, the House River blaze is still keeping forestry officers on their toes with occasional ground starts.</p><p>Rod Houle, forest protection technician in Fort McMurray, said the fire has persisted because of last year's drought. The dry conditions allowed the fire to burn three to four metres deep in the ground.</p><p>"When firefighters are dealing with these wildfire starts, they're dealing with the surface fuels and subsurface fuels,'' Houle said. "But to get to the depth of the fuels can be a real (obstacle).''</p><p>Snow has fallen several times in the region over the last week, which Houle said is welcome. But much more moisture has to hit the ground to protect it against wildfire.</p><p>Last year the department raised the flag on the province's dry conditions and began the fire season a month ahead of schedule. Crews are normally put on alert April 1.</p><p>Houle said it's too soon to tell if another early season is on the calendar.</p><p>"We haven't fleshed out any plans for early fire season starts, but it's pretty dry,'' he said. "Even with this snow, the amount of moisture in it is minimal when you think about it.''</p><p>Forestry officials continue to monitor the House River fire and will determine the start of fire season within the next few months.</p><p>(Fort McMurray Today)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5ST5-2631-F105-6282-00000-00Residents of Temagami return home, but fires continue to burn2018-07-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A2Residents of Temagami return home, but fires continue to burnGabriele Roy The Canadian Press

Residents of a northeastern Ontario community affected by forest fires are back in the homes they were forced to leave earlier this week.

While a mandatory evacuation order has been lifted in Temagami, Ont., firefighters in the area were still battling 25 active fires Friday, said Shayne McCool, fire information officer from the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

Even though they're back in their homes, some residents were still worried by the situation.

"It is not only a fire, it's a forest fire so it won't be done any time soon," said Stephanie Wagner, who owns the Temagami Shores Inn & Resort with her husband.

Wagner said approximately 30 people had to leave the resort, where she lives with her husband and their son, on Sunday. "We were crying and leaving everything behind because our first priority was safety for our staff and our guests," she said. "We drove into town and waited for a few hours but the smoke was so heavy that we had to stay at our friends' house."

They were able to go back to their property Wednesday and are now hosting some of the pilots and staff battling the forest fires in the area, Wagner said.

Despite the fires, Wagner said numerous guests are starting to gather at the resort for a wedding on Saturday.

urn:contentItem:5NWG-7W51-JDH3-G0VW-00000-00Fire threatens renowned national park in Spain2017-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:14ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6Fire threatens renowned national park in SpainJoseph WilsonThe Associated Press

A forest fire in southern Spain forced the evacuation of at least 1,000 people and threatened a national park famous for its biodiversity and endangered species, authorities said Sunday.

The fire started on Saturday night on Spain's southern coast, then advanced east to reach the Donana Nature Reserve, one of the country's most important wildlife sanctuaries and a

UNESCO World Heritage site since 1994.

"The fire has entered in the limits of the reserve, and that is where we are focusing our efforts," Jose Gregorio Fiscal Lopez from the regional Andalusian authority in charge of the environment told Spanish national television.

The reserve protects more than 107,000 hectares considered of extreme ecological value for the mix of ecosystems, including wetlands, dunes and woods. It is a key stop for migratory birds and home to a variety of animals, including about a fifth of the

400 remaining Iberian lynxes.

Ecologists who work in the park are concerned the fire could wipe out some of the area's prized species and terrain.

"We are worried because the impact could be huge," Carlos Molina, an ornithologist who works inside the reserve, said by phone from his home nearby.

"Donana is probably one of the most important areas for birds in all of Europe, and we just happen to be in a nesting season for several species," Molina said.

While Molina said the reserve's endangered Iberian imperial eagle should not be in danger, the area in immediate threat from the fire is territory for the extremely endangered lynx.

Juan Sanchez, director of the Andalucia's forest fire prevention unit, said the fight was "in its critical phase" due to strong winds whipping up the flames.

"Right now, the fire is developing how we expected. The wind is shifting, gaining strength, which is normal as we get to the afternoon," Sanchez said.

"We are managing it, but a change in the direction of the wind could alter the situation."

Susana Diaz, the regional president of Andalusia, said "there's no risk to the population" after about 1,000 people were forced to leave campsites and houses near the town of Moguer, where the fire started on Saturday night.

Diaz said fighting the fire was proving difficult due to hot, dry weather, with temperatures reaching 39 C, and shifting winds. More than 550 firefighters, soldiers and police officers supported by 21 air units were combating the blaze Sunday.

"It's still very early, but we are not ruling out the human factor" as a possible cause of the fire, said Diaz.

Spain's interior minister, Juan Ignacio Zoido, said from a control post near the fire: "We are taking special measures, even though the wind is pushing the fire toward (the reserve) to keep the damage to a minimum."

The fire comes a week after wildfires killed 64 people in neighbouring Portugal.

urn:contentItem:46YX-VM30-01G6-82G6-00000-00<published>2001-05-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:01:14Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BC-Alta-Forest-Fire, Bgt ; Budget; Eds: RECASTS with Chisholm residents allowed to go home; INSERTS comments from resident after para 6; UPDATES fires numbers as of Saturday night, in last graf; See CP Photo; INDEX: Environment, Social, Forestry, Health; HL:Chisholm, Alta., residents allowed home after forest fire forces them out</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Darcy Henton</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Four families in the tiny northern Alberta community of Chisholm were back home Saturday evening after being forced to flee a raging forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">About 12 residents of the hamlet, about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton, had been rousted from their beds early Saturday when flames from the massive fire crept within 400 metres, said Barb Toker, an Alberta fire spokeswoman.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- Six bulldozers and 50 firefighters defended the hamlet's southern limits Saturday as water bombers hammered back the flames enough for the evacuation order to be lifted later in the afternoon.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Rick Strickland, provincial fire information officer, said several of the residents returned after the winds died down and scattered showers drifted over the fire.</p><p>A fireguard was established around the perimeter of the town and a municipal fire truck waited on standby to protect the buildings in the community.</p><p>Firefighters were also working to protect 12 unoccupied summer cottages in the area.</p><p>Marie Ward, 76, who was back on her farm about a kilometre outside of Chisholm on Saturday night, said she didn't want to leave when the evacuation order came.</p><p>"My girls said, "You better take some things. Take the pictures, Mom.' ''</p><p>They grabbed framed pictures off the walls and photo albums. And at Ward's insistence, they also managed to load up a brand-new rug and her chesterfield.</p><p>"It was just terrible. It was burning so hard that we could hear the roar of the fire when they told us we had to leave,'' said Ward.</p><p>She was thankful her house didn't burn down but she did lose an old cabin about 100 metres away which she used to store Christmas decorations for the yard.</p><p>When she arrived home Saturday around suppertime, Ward said the ground was blackened just 50 metres from her doorstep.</p><p>Her daughter, who has a trailer nearby, was spared the trailer but lost three sheds and her outhouse, Ward said.</p><p>She added her son, who lives on land nearby, walked down a road for several hours Friday to lead his two horses and his dog away from the smoke, before relatives arrived with a horse trailer to pick him up.</p><p>Chisholm is on the northern boundary of the 120-square-kilometre fire that is now under attack from more than 200 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters, planes and heavy equipment.</p><p>Thirteen residents of Flatbush, about 20 kilometres to the south, remained on evacuation alert, but winds blowing out of the east Saturday had also given them some respite.</p><p>"The wind is going southwest,'' said Strickland. "It is moving the fire away from Chisholm and the Flatbush area, but who knows what is going to happen tomorrow.''</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush on Friday had earlier been allowed to return to their homes.</p><p>Late Saturday night, conditions remained calm, said Toker.</p><p>She said the Chisholm blaze was the largest fire in Alberta this year.</p><p>Meanwhile, Transport Canada investigators were able to return on Saturday to the scene of a plane crash that killed two people who had been helping fight another fire Friday.</p><p>RCMP removed the bodies of the pilot and passenger of a forest fire spotter plane that crashed on the edge of fire burning northeast of Red Earth Creek, but had to evacuate the area when the fire came within half a kilometre.</p><p>RCMP Cst. Cliff Brennan said investigators were still having difficulty assessing the crash site due to adverse weather conditions. Police said smoke had reduced visibility in the area.</p><p>The names of the victims weren't released.</p><p>The Cessna went down in dense forest in a hilly area.</p><p>Strickland said the passenger in the aircraft was a veteran air attack officer who was mapping out a strategy for water bombers to attack the lightning-caused fire.</p><p>"He went up there to do an initial attack on that fire,'' he said. "It is an unfortunate situation.''</p><p>Strickland said grief counsellors have been sent in to help employees and family deal with the situation.</p><p>The deaths are the first involving Alberta firefighters since a firefighter died fighting a blaze near Mariana Lake, south of Fort McMurray, in May 1995.</p><p>Meanwhile, firefighters were fighting 24 fires in the province after one of the driest winters in Alberta history. As of Saturday night, 10 fires, including the Chisholm fire, were burning out of control.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
